quoteText:
I beg, Catherine, you will always wrap yourself up
very warm about the throat, when you come from the rooms at night; and
I wish you would try to keep some account of the money you spend; I
will give you this little book on purpose.
subQuotationList:
['I beg, Catherine, you will always wrap yourself up
very warm about the throat, when you come from the rooms at night; and
I wish you would try to keep some account of the money you spend; I
will give you this little book on purpose.']
speaker: Mrs. Morland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText:
I wish you could dance, my dear I wish you could
get a partner.
subQuotationList: ['I wish you could dance, my dear I wish you could\nget a partner.']
speaker: Mrs. Allen
referringExpression: Mrs Allen did all that she could do in such a case by saying

quoteText:
It would have been very
shocking to have it torn, would not it? It is such a
delicate muslin. For my part I have not seen anything I like so well in
the whole room, I assure you.
subQuotationList:
['It would have been very
shocking to have it torn,', 'would not it? It is such a
delicate muslin. For my part I have not seen anything I like so well in
the whole room, I assure you.']
speaker: Mrs. Allen

quoteText:
How uncomfortable it is, not to have a single
acquaintance here!
subQuotationList: ['How uncomfortable it is,', 'not to have a single\nacquaintance here!']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Yes, my dear, it is very
uncomfortable indeed.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, my dear,', 'it is very\nuncomfortable indeed.']
speaker: Mrs. Allen

quoteText:
What shall we do? The gentlemen and ladies at this table look as if
they wondered why we came here we seem forcing ourselves into their
party.
subQuotationList: ['What shall we do? The gentlemen and ladies at this table look as if\nthey wondered why we came here we seem forcing ourselves into their\nparty.']
speaker: Catherine Morland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Allen', 'Catherine Morland'], ['Mrs. Allen', 'Catherine Morland'], ['Mrs. Allen', 'Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText:
Aye, so we do. That is very disagreeable. I wish we had a large
acquaintance here.
subQuotationList: ['Aye, so we do. That is very disagreeable. I wish we had a large\nacquaintance here.']
speaker: Mrs. Allen

quoteText: I wish we had _any;_ it would be somebody to go to.
subQuotationList: ['I wish we had _any;_ it would be somebody to go to.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Very true, my dear; and if we knew anybody we would join them
directly. The Skinners were here last year I wish they were here now.
subQuotationList: ['Very true, my dear; and if we knew anybody we would join them\ndirectly. The Skinners were here last year I wish they were here now.']
speaker: Mrs. Allen

quoteText:
Had not we better go away as it is? Here are no tea-things for us, you
see.
subQuotationList: ['Had not we better go away as it is? Here are no tea-things for us, you\nsee.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
No more there are, indeed. How very provoking! But I think we had
better sit still, for one gets so tumbled in such a crowd! How is my
head, my dear? Somebody gave me a push that has hurt it, I am afraid.
subQuotationList: ['No more there are, indeed. How very provoking! But I think we had\nbetter sit still, for one gets so tumbled in such a crowd! How is my\nhead, my dear? Somebody gave me a push that has hurt it, I am afraid.']
speaker: Mrs. Allen

quoteText:
No, indeed, it looks very nice. But, dear Mrs. Allen, are you sure
there is nobody you know in all this multitude of people? I think you
_must_ know somebody.
subQuotationList: ['No, indeed, it looks very nice. But, dear Mrs. Allen, are you sure\nthere is nobody you know in all this multitude of people? I think you\n_must_ know somebody.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
I don t, upon my word I wish I did. I wish I had a large acquaintance
here with all my heart, and then I should get you a partner. I should
be so glad to have you dance. There goes a strange-looking woman! What
an odd gown she has got on! How old-fashioned it is! Look at the back.
subQuotationList:
['I don t, upon my word I wish I did. I wish I had a large acquaintance
here with all my heart, and then I should get you a partner. I should
be so glad to have you dance. There goes a strange-looking woman! What
an odd gown she has got on! How old-fashioned it is! Look at the back.']
speaker: Mrs. Allen

quoteText:
Well, Miss Morland, I hope you have had an
agreeable ball.
subQuotationList: ['Well, Miss Morland,', 'I hope you have had an\nagreeable ball.']
speaker: Mr. Allen

quoteText: Very agreeable indeed,
subQuotationList: ['Very agreeable indeed,']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
I wish she had been able to dance, I wish we could
have got a partner for her. I have been saying how glad I should be if
the Skinners were here this winter instead of last; or if the Parrys
had come, as they talked of once, she might have danced with George
Parry. I am so sorry she has not had a partner!
subQuotationList:
['I wish she had been able to dance,', 'I wish we could
have got a partner for her. I have been saying how glad I should be if
the Skinners were here this winter instead of last; or if the Parrys
had come, as they talked of once, she might have danced with George
Parry. I am so sorry she has not had a partner!']
speaker: Mrs. Allen
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Catherine Morland']], [['Mrs. Allen', 'Mr. Allen'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText: We shall do better another evening I hope,
subQuotationList: ['We shall do better another evening I hope,']
speaker: Mr. Allen

quoteText:
I have hitherto
been very remiss, madam, in the proper attentions of a partner here; I
have not yet asked you how long you have been in Bath; whether you were
ever here before; whether you have been at the Upper Rooms, the
theatre, and the concert; and how you like the place altogether. I have
been very negligent but are you now at leisure to satisfy me in these
particulars? If you are I will begin directly.
subQuotationList:
['I have hitherto
been very remiss, madam, in the proper attentions of a partner here; I
have not yet asked you how long you have been in Bath; whether you were
ever here before; whether you have been at the Upper Rooms, the
theatre, and the concert; and how you like the place altogether. I have
been very negligent but are you now at leisure to satisfy me in these
particulars? If you are I will begin directly.']
speaker: Henry Tilney
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText: You need not give yourself that trouble, sir.
subQuotationList: ['You need not give yourself that trouble, sir.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: No trouble, I assure you, madam. Have you been long in Bath, madam?
subQuotationList: ['No trouble, I assure you, madam.', 'Have you been long in Bath, madam?']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText: About a week, sir,
subQuotationList: ['About a week, sir,']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: Really!
subQuotationList: ['Really!']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText: Why should you be surprised, sir?
subQuotationList: ['Why should you be surprised, sir?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Why, indeed! But some emotion must
appear to be raised by your reply, and surprise is more easily assumed,
and not less reasonable than any other. Now let us go on. Were you
never here before, madam?
subQuotationList:
['Why, indeed!', 'But some emotion must
appear to be raised by your reply, and surprise is more easily assumed,
and not less reasonable than any other. Now let us go on. Were you
never here before, madam?']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText: Never, sir.
subQuotationList: ['Never, sir.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: Indeed! Have you yet honoured the Upper Rooms?
subQuotationList: ['Indeed! Have you yet honoured the Upper Rooms?']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText: Yes, sir, I was there last Monday.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, sir, I was there last Monday.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: Have you been to the theatre?
subQuotationList: ['Have you been to the theatre?']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText: Yes, sir, I was at the play on Tuesday.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, sir, I was at the play on Tuesday.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: To the concert?
subQuotationList: ['To the concert?']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText: Yes, sir, on Wednesday.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, sir, on Wednesday.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: And are you altogether pleased with Bath?
subQuotationList: ['And are you altogether pleased with Bath?']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText: Yes I like it very well.
subQuotationList: ['Yes I like it very well.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: Now I must give one smirk, and then we may be rational again.
subQuotationList: ['Now I must give one smirk, and then we may be rational again.']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText:
I see what you think of me, I shall make
but a poor figure in your journal tomorrow.
subQuotationList: ['I see what you think of me,', 'I shall make\nbut a poor figure in your journal tomorrow.']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText: My journal!
subQuotationList: ['My journal!']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Yes, I know exactly what you will say: Friday, went to the Lower
Rooms; wore my sprigged muslin robe with blue trimmings plain black
shoes appeared to much advantage; but was strangely harassed by a
queer, half-witted man, who would make me dance with him, and
distressed me by his nonsense.
subQuotationList:
['Yes, I know exactly what you will say: Friday, went to the Lower
Rooms; wore my sprigged muslin robe with blue trimmings plain black
shoes appeared to much advantage; but was strangely harassed by a
queer, half-witted man, who would make me dance with him, and
distressed me by his nonsense.']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText: Indeed I shall say no such thing.
subQuotationList: ['Indeed I shall say no such thing.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: Shall I tell you what you ought to say?
subQuotationList: ['Shall I tell you what you ought to say?']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText: If you please.
subQuotationList: ['If you please.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
I danced with a very agreeable young man, introduced by Mr. King; had
a great deal of conversation with him seems a most extraordinary
genius hope I may know more of him. _That_, madam, is what I _wish_ you
to say.
subQuotationList:
['I danced with a very agreeable young man, introduced by Mr. King; had
a great deal of conversation with him seems a most extraordinary
genius hope I may know more of him. _That_, madam, is what I _wish_ you
to say.']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText: But, perhaps, I keep no journal.
subQuotationList: ['But, perhaps, I keep no journal.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Perhaps you are not sitting in this room, and I am not sitting by you.
These are points in which a doubt is equally possible. Not keep a
journal! How are your absent cousins to understand the tenour of your
life in Bath without one? How are the civilities and compliments of
every day to be related as they ought to be, unless noted down every
evening in a journal? How are your various dresses to be remembered,
and the particular state of your complexion, and curl of your hair to
be described in all their diversities, without having constant recourse
to a journal? My dear madam, I am not so ignorant of young ladies  ways
as you wish to believe me; it is this delightful habit of journaling
which largely contributes to form the easy style of writing for which
ladies are so generally celebrated. Everybody allows that the talent of
writing agreeable letters is peculiarly female. Nature may have done
something, but I am sure it must be essentially assisted by the
practice of keeping a journal.
subQuotationList:
['Perhaps you are not sitting in this room, and I am not sitting by you.
These are points in which a doubt is equally possible. Not keep a
journal! How are your absent cousins to understand the tenour of your
life in Bath without one? How are the civilities and compliments of
every day to be related as they ought to be, unless noted down every
evening in a journal? How are your various dresses to be remembered,
and the particular state of your complexion, and curl of your hair to
be described in all their diversities, without having constant recourse
to a journal? My dear madam, I am not so ignorant of young ladies  ways
as you wish to believe me; it is this delightful habit of journaling
which largely contributes to form the easy style of writing for which
ladies are so generally celebrated. Everybody allows that the talent of
writing agreeable letters is peculiarly female. Nature may have done
something, but I am sure it must be essentially assisted by the
practice of keeping a journal.']
speaker: Henry Tilney
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText:
I have sometimes thought, whether ladies
do write so much better letters than gentlemen! That is I should not
think the superiority was always on our side.
subQuotationList: ['I have sometimes thought,', 'whether ladies\ndo write so much better letters than gentlemen! That is I should not\nthink the superiority was always on our side.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
As far as I have had opportunity of judging, it appears to me that the
usual style of letter-writing among women is faultless, except in three
particulars.
subQuotationList: ['As far as I have had opportunity of judging, it appears to me that the\nusual style of letter-writing among women is faultless, except in three\nparticulars.']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText: And what are they?
subQuotationList: ['And what are they?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
A general deficiency of subject, a total inattention to stops, and a
very frequent ignorance of grammar.
subQuotationList: ['A general deficiency of subject, a total inattention to stops, and a\nvery frequent ignorance of grammar.']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText:
Upon my word! I need not have been afraid of disclaiming the
compliment. You do not think too highly of us in that way.
subQuotationList: ['Upon my word! I need not have been afraid of disclaiming the\ncompliment. You do not think too highly of us in that way.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
I should no more lay it down as a general rule that women write better
letters than men, than that they sing better duets, or draw better
landscapes. In every power, of which taste is the foundation,
excellence is pretty fairly divided between the sexes.
subQuotationList:
['I should no more lay it down as a general rule that women write better
letters than men, than that they sing better duets, or draw better
landscapes. In every power, of which taste is the foundation,
excellence is pretty fairly divided between the sexes.']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText:
My dear Catherine, do
take this pin out of my sleeve; I am afraid it has torn a hole already;
I shall be quite sorry if it has, for this is a favourite gown, though
it cost but nine shillings a yard.
subQuotationList:
['My dear Catherine,', 'do
take this pin out of my sleeve; I am afraid it has torn a hole already;
I shall be quite sorry if it has, for this is a favourite gown, though
it cost but nine shillings a yard.']
speaker: Mrs. Allen
referringExpression: They were interrupted by Mrs Allen

quoteText: That is exactly what I should have guessed it, madam,
subQuotationList: ['That is exactly what I should have guessed it, madam,']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText: Do you understand muslins, sir?
subQuotationList: ['Do you understand muslins, sir?']
speaker: Mrs. Allen

quoteText:
Particularly well; I always buy my own cravats, and am allowed to be
an excellent judge; and my sister has often trusted me in the choice of
a gown. I bought one for her the other day, and it was pronounced to be
a prodigious bargain by every lady who saw it. I gave but five
shillings a yard for it, and a true Indian muslin.
subQuotationList:
['Particularly well; I always buy my own cravats, and am allowed to be
an excellent judge; and my sister has often trusted me in the choice of
a gown. I bought one for her the other day, and it was pronounced to be
a prodigious bargain by every lady who saw it. I gave but five
shillings a yard for it, and a true Indian muslin.']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText:
Men commonly take so little
notice of those things, I can never get Mr. Allen to know
one of my gowns from another. You must be a great comfort to your
sister, sir.
subQuotationList:
['Men commonly take so little
notice of those things,', 'I can never get Mr. Allen to know
one of my gowns from another. You must be a great comfort to your
sister, sir.']
speaker: Mrs. Allen

quoteText: I hope I am, madam.
subQuotationList: ['I hope I am, madam.']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText: And pray, sir, what do you think of Miss Morland s gown?
subQuotationList: ['And pray, sir, what do you think of Miss Morland s gown?']
speaker: Mrs. Allen

quoteText:
It is very pretty, madam, but I do
not think it will wash well; I am afraid it will fray.
subQuotationList: ['It is very pretty, madam,', 'but I do\nnot think it will wash well; I am afraid it will fray.']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText: How can you, be so
subQuotationList: ['How can you,', 'be so']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
I am quite of your opinion, sir, and so I told
Miss Morland when she bought it.
subQuotationList: ['I am quite of your opinion, sir,', 'and so I told\nMiss Morland when she bought it.']
speaker: Mrs. Allen

quoteText:
But then you know, madam, muslin always turns to some account or
other; Miss Morland will get enough out of it for a handkerchief, or a
cap, or a cloak. Muslin can never be said to be wasted. I have heard my
sister say so forty times, when she has been extravagant in buying more
than she wanted, or careless in cutting it to pieces.
subQuotationList:
['But then you know, madam, muslin always turns to some account or
other; Miss Morland will get enough out of it for a handkerchief, or a
cap, or a cloak. Muslin can never be said to be wasted. I have heard my
sister say so forty times, when she has been extravagant in buying more
than she wanted, or careless in cutting it to pieces.']
speaker: Henry Tilney
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Allen'], ['Mrs. Allen'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Eleanor Tilney'], ['Eleanor Tilney'], ['Eleanor Tilney']]]

quoteText:
Bath is a charming place, sir; there are so many good shops here. We
are sadly off in the country; not but what we have very good shops in
Salisbury, but it is so far to go eight miles is a long way; Mr. Allen
says it is nine, measured nine; but I am sure it cannot be more than
eight; and it is such a fag I come back tired to death. Now, here one
can step out of doors and get a thing in five minutes.
subQuotationList:
['Bath is a charming place, sir; there are so many good shops here. We
are sadly off in the country; not but what we have very good shops in
Salisbury, but it is so far to go eight miles is a long way; Mr. Allen
says it is nine, measured nine; but I am sure it cannot be more than
eight; and it is such a fag I come back tired to death. Now, here one
can step out of doors and get a thing in five minutes.']
speaker: Mrs. Allen
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Henry Tilney'], ['Mrs. Allen', 'Mr. Allen'], ['Mr. Allen', 'Mrs. Allen'], ['Mr. Allen']]]

quoteText:
What are you
thinking of so earnestly? not of your partner, I hope, for, by that shake of the head,
your meditations are not satisfactory.
subQuotationList: ['What are you\nthinking of so earnestly?', 'not of your partner, I hope, for, by that shake of the head,\nyour meditations are not satisfactory.']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText: I was not thinking of anything.
subQuotationList: ['I was not thinking of anything.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
That is artful and deep, to be sure; but I had rather be told at once
that you will not tell me.
subQuotationList: ['That is artful and deep, to be sure; but I had rather be told at once\nthat you will not tell me.']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText: Well then, I will not.
subQuotationList: ['Well then, I will not.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Thank you; for now we shall soon be acquainted, as I am authorized to
tease you on this subject whenever we meet, and nothing in the world
advances intimacy so much.
subQuotationList: ['Thank you; for now we shall soon be acquainted, as I am authorized to\ntease you on this subject whenever we meet, and nothing in the world\nadvances intimacy so much.']
speaker: Henry Tilney
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Catherine Morland'], ['Henry Tilney', 'Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Henry Tilney', 'Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText:
What a delightful place Bath
is, and how pleasant it would be
if we had any acquaintance here.
subQuotationList: ['What a delightful place Bath\nis,', 'and how pleasant it would be\nif we had any acquaintance here.']
speaker: Mrs. Allen

quoteText:
I think, madam, I cannot be mistaken; it
is a long time since I had the pleasure of seeing you, but is not your
name Allen?
subQuotationList: ['I think, madam, I cannot be mistaken; it\nis a long time since I had the pleasure of seeing you, but is not your\nname Allen?']
speaker: Mrs. Thorpe
referringExpression: a lady of about her own age who was sitting by her and had been looking at her attentively for several minutes addressed her

quoteText:
Here come my dear girls, My dear Mrs. Allen, I long to introduce them; they will be so
delighted to see you: the tallest is Isabella, my eldest; is not she a
fine young woman? The others are very much admired too, but I believe
Isabella is the handsomest.
subQuotationList:
['Here come my dear girls,', 'My dear Mrs. Allen, I long to introduce them; they will be so
delighted to see you: the tallest is Isabella, my eldest; is not she a
fine young woman? The others are very much admired too, but I believe
Isabella is the handsomest.']
speaker: Mrs. Thorpe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Isabella Thorpe']], [['Mrs. Allen'], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Mrs. Allen'], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Isabella Thorpe']]]

quoteText:
How excessively like her
brother Miss Morland is!
subQuotationList: ['How excessively like her\nbrother Miss Morland is!']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe
referringExpression: the eldest young lady observed aloud to the rest

quoteText:
The very picture of him indeed! I should have
known her anywhere for his sister!
subQuotationList: ['The very picture of him indeed!', 'I should have\nknown her anywhere for his sister!']
speaker: Mrs. Thorpe

quoteText:
How glad I am we have met with Mrs.
Thorpe!
subQuotationList: ['How glad I am we have met with Mrs.\nThorpe!']
speaker: Mrs. Allen

quoteText:
My dearest
creature, what can have made you so late? I have been waiting for you
at least this age!
subQuotationList: ['My dearest\ncreature, what can have made you so late? I have been waiting for you\nat least this age!']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe

quoteText:
Have you, indeed! I am very sorry for it; but really I thought I was
in very good time. It is but just one. I hope you have not been here
long?
subQuotationList: ['Have you, indeed! I am very sorry for it; but really I thought I was\nin very good time. It is but just one. I hope you have not been here\nlong?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Oh! These ten ages at least. I am sure I have been here this half
hour. But now, let us go and sit down at the other end of the room, and
enjoy ourselves. I have an hundred things to say to you. In the first
place, I was so afraid it would rain this morning, just as I wanted to
set off; it looked very showery, and that would have thrown me into
agonies! Do you know, I saw the prettiest hat you can imagine, in a
shop window in Milsom Street just now very like yours, only with
coquelicot ribbons instead of green; I quite longed for it. But, my
dearest Catherine, what have you been doing with yourself all this
morning? Have you gone on with Udolpho?
subQuotationList:
['Oh! These ten ages at least. I am sure I have been here this half
hour. But now, let us go and sit down at the other end of the room, and
enjoy ourselves. I have an hundred things to say to you. In the first
place, I was so afraid it would rain this morning, just as I wanted to
set off; it looked very showery, and that would have thrown me into
agonies! Do you know, I saw the prettiest hat you can imagine, in a
shop window in Milsom Street just now very like yours, only with
coquelicot ribbons instead of green; I quite longed for it. But, my
dearest Catherine, what have you been doing with yourself all this
morning? Have you gone on with Udolpho?']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Isabella Thorpe', 'Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText:
Yes, I have been reading it ever since I woke; and I am got to the
black veil.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I have been reading it ever since I woke; and I am got to the\nblack veil.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Are you, indeed? How delightful! Oh! I would not tell you what is
behind the black veil for the world! Are not you wild to know?
subQuotationList: ['Are you, indeed? How delightful! Oh! I would not tell you what is\nbehind the black veil for the world! Are not you wild to know?']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe

quoteText:
Oh! Yes, quite; what can it be? But do not tell me I would not be told
upon any account. I know it must be a skeleton, I am sure it is
Laurentina s skeleton. Oh! I am delighted with the book! I should like
to spend my whole life in reading it. I assure you, if it had not been
to meet you, I would not have come away from it for all the world.
subQuotationList:
['Oh! Yes, quite; what can it be? But do not tell me I would not be told
upon any account. I know it must be a skeleton, I am sure it is
Laurentina s skeleton. Oh! I am delighted with the book! I should like
to spend my whole life in reading it. I assure you, if it had not been
to meet you, I would not have come away from it for all the world.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Dear creature! How much I am obliged to you; and when you have
finished Udolpho, we will read the Italian together; and I have made
out a list of ten or twelve more of the same kind for you.
subQuotationList: ['Dear creature! How much I am obliged to you; and when you have\nfinished Udolpho, we will read the Italian together; and I have made\nout a list of ten or twelve more of the same kind for you.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Isabella Thorpe', 'Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText: Have you, indeed! How glad I am! What are they all?
subQuotationList: ['Have you, indeed! How glad I am! What are they all?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
I will read you their names directly; here they are, in my pocketbook.
Castle of Wolfenbach, Clermont, Mysterious Warnings, Necromancer of the
Black Forest, Midnight Bell, Orphan of the Rhine, and Horrid Mysteries.
Those will last us some time.
subQuotationList:
['I will read you their names directly; here they are, in my pocketbook.
Castle of Wolfenbach, Clermont, Mysterious Warnings, Necromancer of the
Black Forest, Midnight Bell, Orphan of the Rhine, and Horrid Mysteries.
Those will last us some time.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe

quoteText:
Yes, pretty well; but are they all horrid, are you sure they are all
horrid?
subQuotationList: ['Yes, pretty well; but are they all horrid, are you sure they are all\nhorrid?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Yes, quite sure; for a particular friend of mine, a Miss Andrews, a
sweet girl, one of the sweetest creatures in the world, has read every
one of them. I wish you knew Miss Andrews, you would be delighted with
her. She is netting herself the sweetest cloak you can conceive. I
think her as beautiful as an angel, and I am so vexed with the men for
not admiring her! I scold them all amazingly about it.
subQuotationList:
['Yes, quite sure; for a particular friend of mine, a Miss Andrews, a
sweet girl, one of the sweetest creatures in the world, has read every
one of them. I wish you knew Miss Andrews, you would be delighted with
her. She is netting herself the sweetest cloak you can conceive. I
think her as beautiful as an angel, and I am so vexed with the men for
not admiring her! I scold them all amazingly about it.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe

quoteText: Scold them! Do you scold them for not admiring her?
subQuotationList: ['Scold them! Do you scold them for not admiring her?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Yes, that I do. There is nothing I would not do for those who are
really my friends. I have no notion of loving people by halves; it is
not my nature. My attachments are always excessively strong. I told
Captain Hunt at one of our assemblies this winter that if he was to
tease me all night, I would not dance with him, unless he would allow
Miss Andrews to be as beautiful as an angel. The men think us incapable
of real friendship, you know, and I am determined to show them the
difference. Now, if I were to hear anybody speak slightingly of you, I
should fire up in a moment: but that is not at all likely, for _you_
are just the kind of girl to be a great favourite with the men.
subQuotationList:
['Yes, that I do. There is nothing I would not do for those who are
really my friends. I have no notion of loving people by halves; it is
not my nature. My attachments are always excessively strong. I told
Captain Hunt at one of our assemblies this winter that if he was to
tease me all night, I would not dance with him, unless he would allow
Miss Andrews to be as beautiful as an angel. The men think us incapable
of real friendship, you know, and I am determined to show them the
difference. Now, if I were to hear anybody speak slightingly of you, I
should fire up in a moment: but that is not at all likely, for _you_
are just the kind of girl to be a great favourite with the men.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe

quoteText: Oh, dear! How can you say so?
subQuotationList: ['Oh, dear!', 'How can you say so?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
I know you very well; you have so much animation, which is exactly
what Miss Andrews wants, for I must confess there is something
amazingly insipid about her. Oh! I must tell you, that just after we
parted yesterday, I saw a young man looking at you so earnestly I am
sure he is in love with you.
subQuotationList:
['I know you very well; you have so much animation, which is exactly
what Miss Andrews wants, for I must confess there is something
amazingly insipid about her. Oh! I must tell you, that just after we
parted yesterday, I saw a young man looking at you so earnestly I am
sure he is in love with you.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland', 'Isabella Thorpe'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText:
It is very true, upon my honour, but I see how it
is; you are indifferent to everybody s admiration, except that of one
gentleman, who shall be nameless. Nay, I cannot blame you
subQuotationList: ['It is very true, upon my honour, but I see how it\nis; you are indifferent to everybody s admiration, except that of one\ngentleman, who shall be nameless. Nay, I cannot blame you']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe

quoteText:
your feelings are easily understood. Where the heart is
really attached, I know very well how little one can be pleased with
the attention of anybody else. Everything is so insipid, so
uninteresting, that does not relate to the beloved object! I can
perfectly comprehend your feelings.
subQuotationList:
['your feelings are easily understood. Where the heart is
really attached, I know very well how little one can be pleased with
the attention of anybody else. Everything is so insipid, so
uninteresting, that does not relate to the beloved object! I can
perfectly comprehend your feelings.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe

quoteText:
But you should not persuade me that I think so very much about Mr.
Tilney, for perhaps I may never see him again.
subQuotationList: ['But you should not persuade me that I think so very much about Mr.\nTilney, for perhaps I may never see him again.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Not see him again! My dearest creature, do not talk of it. I am sure
you would be miserable if you thought so!
subQuotationList: ['Not see him again! My dearest creature, do not talk of it. I am sure\nyou would be miserable if you thought so!']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe

quoteText:
No, indeed, I should not. I do not pretend to say that I was not very
much pleased with him; but while I have Udolpho to read, I feel as if
nobody could make me miserable. Oh! The dreadful black veil! My dear
Isabella, I am sure there must be Laurentina s skeleton behind it.
subQuotationList:
['No, indeed, I should not. I do not pretend to say that I was not very
much pleased with him; but while I have Udolpho to read, I feel as if
nobody could make me miserable. Oh! The dreadful black veil! My dear
Isabella, I am sure there must be Laurentina s skeleton behind it.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
It is so odd to me, that you should never have read Udolpho before;
but I suppose Mrs. Morland objects to novels.
subQuotationList: ['It is so odd to me, that you should never have read Udolpho before;\nbut I suppose Mrs. Morland objects to novels.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe

quoteText:
No, she does not. She very often reads Sir Charles Grandison herself;
but new books do not fall in our way.
subQuotationList: ['No, she does not. She very often reads Sir Charles Grandison herself;\nbut new books do not fall in our way.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Sir Charles Grandison! That is an amazing horrid book, is it not? I
remember Miss Andrews could not get through the first volume.
subQuotationList: ['Sir Charles Grandison! That is an amazing horrid book, is it not? I\nremember Miss Andrews could not get through the first volume.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe

quoteText:
It is not like Udolpho at all; but yet I think it is very
entertaining.
subQuotationList: ['It is not like Udolpho at all; but yet I think it is very\nentertaining.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Do you indeed! You surprise me; I thought it had not been readable.
But, my dearest Catherine, have you settled what to wear on your head
tonight? I am determined at all events to be dressed exactly like you.
The men take notice of _that_ sometimes, you know.
subQuotationList:
['Do you indeed! You surprise me; I thought it had not been readable.
But, my dearest Catherine, have you settled what to wear on your head
tonight? I am determined at all events to be dressed exactly like you.
The men take notice of _that_ sometimes, you know.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText: But it does not signify if they do,
subQuotationList: ['But it does not signify if they do,']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Signify! Oh, heavens! I make it a rule never to mind what they say.
They are very often amazingly impertinent if you do not treat them with
spirit, and make them keep their distance.
subQuotationList: ['Signify! Oh, heavens! I make it a rule never to mind what they say.\nThey are very often amazingly impertinent if you do not treat them with\nspirit, and make them keep their distance.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe

quoteText:
Are they? Well, I never observed _that_. They always behave very well
to me.
subQuotationList: ['Are they? Well, I never observed _that_. They always behave very well\nto me.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Oh! They give themselves such airs. They are the most conceited
creatures in the world, and think themselves of so much importance! By
the by, though I have thought of it a hundred times, I have always
forgot to ask you what is your favourite complexion in a man. Do you
like them best dark or fair?
subQuotationList:
['Oh! They give themselves such airs. They are the most conceited
creatures in the world, and think themselves of so much importance! By
the by, though I have thought of it a hundred times, I have always
forgot to ask you what is your favourite complexion in a man. Do you
like them best dark or fair?']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe

quoteText:
I hardly know. I never much thought about it. Something between both,
I think. Brown not fair, and and not very dark.
subQuotationList: ['I hardly know. I never much thought about it. Something between both,\nI think. Brown not fair, and and not very dark.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Very well, Catherine. That is exactly he. I have not forgot your
description of Mr. Tilney  a brown skin, with dark eyes, and rather
dark hair.  Well, my taste is different. I prefer light eyes, and as to
complexion do you know I like a sallow better than any other. You must
not betray me, if you should ever meet with one of your acquaintance
answering that description.
subQuotationList:
['Very well, Catherine. That is exactly he. I have not forgot your
description of Mr. Tilney  a brown skin, with dark eyes, and rather
dark hair.  Well, my taste is different. I prefer light eyes, and as to
complexion do you know I like a sallow better than any other. You must
not betray me, if you should ever meet with one of your acquaintance
answering that description.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Catherine Morland'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText: Betray you! What do you mean?
subQuotationList: ['Betray you! What do you mean?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Nay, do not distress me. I believe I have said too much. Let us drop
the subject.
subQuotationList: ['Nay, do not distress me. I believe I have said too much. Let us drop\nthe subject.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe

quoteText:
For heaven s sake!
Let us move away from this end of the room. Do you know, there are two
odious young men who have been staring at me this half hour. They
really put me quite out of countenance. Let us go and look at the
arrivals. They will hardly follow us there.
subQuotationList:
['For heaven s sake!
Let us move away from this end of the room. Do you know, there are two
odious young men who have been staring at me this half hour. They
really put me quite out of countenance. Let us go and look at the
arrivals. They will hardly follow us there.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe
referringExpression: her friend prevented her by saying
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Isabella Thorpe', 'Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Isabella Thorpe', 'Catherine Morland'], ['Isabella Thorpe', 'Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText:
They are not coming this way, are they? I hope they are not so
impertinent as to follow us. Pray let me know if they are coming. I am
determined I will not look up.
subQuotationList: ['They are not coming this way, are they? I hope they are not so\nimpertinent as to follow us. Pray let me know if they are coming. I am\ndetermined I will not look up.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe

quoteText: And which way are they gone? One was a very good-looking young man.
subQuotationList: ['And which way are they gone?', 'One was a very good-looking young man.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe

quoteText: They went towards the church-yard.
subQuotationList: ['They went towards the church-yard.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Well, I am amazingly glad I have got rid of them! And now, what say
you to going to Edgar s Buildings with me, and looking at my new hat?
You said you should like to see it.
subQuotationList: ['Well, I am amazingly glad I have got rid of them! And now, what say\nyou to going to Edgar s Buildings with me, and looking at my new hat?\nYou said you should like to see it.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe

quoteText:
Only, perhaps we may overtake
the two young men.
subQuotationList: ['Only,', 'perhaps we may overtake\nthe two young men.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Oh! Never mind that. If we make haste, we shall pass by them
presently, and I am dying to show you my hat.
subQuotationList: ['Oh! Never mind that. If we make haste, we shall pass by them\npresently, and I am dying to show you my hat.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe

quoteText:
But if we only wait a few minutes, there will be no danger of our
seeing them at all.
subQuotationList: ['But if we only wait a few minutes, there will be no danger of our\nseeing them at all.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
I shall not pay them any such compliment, I assure you. I have no
notion of treating men with such respect. _That_ is the way to spoil
them.
subQuotationList: ['I shall not pay them any such compliment, I assure you. I have no\nnotion of treating men with such respect. _That_ is the way to spoil\nthem.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe

quoteText:
Oh, these odious gigs! How I detest
them.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, these odious gigs!', 'How I detest\nthem.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe

quoteText:
Delightful! Mr. Morland and my
brother!
subQuotationList: ['Delightful! Mr. Morland and my\nbrother!']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe

quoteText: Good heaven!  Tis James!
subQuotationList: ['Good heaven!  Tis James!']
speaker: Catherine Morland
referringExpression: was uttered at the same moment by Catherine

quoteText:
How long do you think we
have been running it from Tetbury, Miss Morland?
subQuotationList: ['How long do you think we\nhave been running it from Tetbury, Miss Morland?']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText: I do not know the distance.
subQuotationList: ['I do not know the distance.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: _Three_-and-twenty!
subQuotationList: ['_Three_-and-twenty!']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText: five-and-twenty if it is an inch.
subQuotationList: ['five-and-twenty if it is an inch.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText:
I know it must be five-and-twenty, by the
time we have been doing it. It is now half after one; we drove out of
the inn-yard at Tetbury as the town clock struck eleven; and I defy any
man in England to make my horse go less than ten miles an hour in
harness; that makes it exactly twenty-five.
subQuotationList:
['I know it must be five-and-twenty,', 'by the
time we have been doing it. It is now half after one; we drove out of
the inn-yard at Tetbury as the town clock struck eleven; and I defy any
man in England to make my horse go less than ten miles an hour in
harness; that makes it exactly twenty-five.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText:
You have lost an hour, it was only ten o clock when we
came from Tetbury.
subQuotationList: ['You have lost an hour,', 'it was only ten o clock when we\ncame from Tetbury.']
speaker: James Morland

quoteText:
Ten o clock! It was eleven, upon my soul! I counted every stroke. This
brother of yours would persuade me out of my senses, Miss Morland; do
but look at my horse; did you ever see an animal so made for speed in
your life?
subQuotationList:
['Ten o clock! It was eleven, upon my soul! I counted every stroke. This
brother of yours would persuade me out of my senses, Miss Morland; do
but look at my horse; did you ever see an animal so made for speed in
your life?']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText:
Such true blood! Three hours and and a half indeed coming only
three and twenty miles! Look at that creature, and suppose it possible
if you can.
subQuotationList: ['Such true blood! Three hours and and a half indeed coming only\nthree and twenty miles! Look at that creature, and suppose it possible\nif you can.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText: He _does_ look very hot, to be sure.
subQuotationList: ['He _does_ look very hot, to be sure.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Hot! He had not turned a hair till we came to Walcot Church; but look
at his forehand; look at his loins; only see how he moves; that horse
_cannot_ go less than ten miles an hour: tie his legs and he will get
on. What do you think of my gig, Miss Morland? A neat one, is not it?
Well hung; town-built; I have not had it a month. It was built for a
Christchurch man, a friend of mine, a very good sort of fellow; he ran
it a few weeks, till, I believe, it was convenient to have done with
it. I happened just then to be looking out for some light thing of the
kind, though I had pretty well determined on a curricle too; but I
chanced to meet him on Magdalen Bridge, as he was driving into Oxford,
last term:  Ah! Thorpe,  said he,  do you happen to want such a little
thing as this? It is a capital one of the kind, but I am cursed tired
of it.   Oh! D ,  said I;  I am your man; what do you ask?  And how
much do you think he did, Miss Morland?
subQuotationList:
['Hot! He had not turned a hair till we came to Walcot Church; but look
at his forehand; look at his loins; only see how he moves; that horse
_cannot_ go less than ten miles an hour: tie his legs and he will get
on. What do you think of my gig, Miss Morland? A neat one, is not it?
Well hung; town-built; I have not had it a month. It was built for a
Christchurch man, a friend of mine, a very good sort of fellow; he ran
it a few weeks, till, I believe, it was convenient to have done with
it. I happened just then to be looking out for some light thing of the
kind, though I had pretty well determined on a curricle too; but I
chanced to meet him on Magdalen Bridge, as he was driving into Oxford,
last term:  Ah! Thorpe,  said he,  do you happen to want such a little
thing as this? It is a capital one of the kind, but I am cursed tired
of it.   Oh! D ,  said I;  I am your man; what do you ask?  And how
much do you think he did, Miss Morland?']
speaker: John Thorpe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['John Thorpe', 'James Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['John Thorpe'], ['John Thorpe'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText: I am sure I cannot guess at all.
subQuotationList: ['I am sure I cannot guess at all.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Curricle-hung, you see; seat, trunk, sword-case, splashing-board,
lamps, silver moulding, all you see complete; the iron-work as good as
new, or better. He asked fifty guineas; I closed with him directly,
threw down the money, and the carriage was mine.
subQuotationList:
['Curricle-hung, you see; seat, trunk, sword-case, splashing-board,
lamps, silver moulding, all you see complete; the iron-work as good as
new, or better. He asked fifty guineas; I closed with him directly,
threw down the money, and the carriage was mine.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText:
And I am sure, I know so little of such things that
I cannot judge whether it was cheap or dear.
subQuotationList: ['And I am sure,', 'I know so little of such things that\nI cannot judge whether it was cheap or dear.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Neither one nor t other; I might have got it for less, I dare say; but
I hate haggling, and poor Freeman wanted cash.
subQuotationList: ['Neither one nor t other; I might have got it for less, I dare say; but\nI hate haggling, and poor Freeman wanted cash.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText: That was very good-natured of you,
subQuotationList: ['That was very good-natured of you,']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Oh! D   it, when one has the means of doing a kind thing by a friend,
I hate to be pitiful.
subQuotationList: ['Oh! D   it, when one has the means of doing a kind thing by a friend,\nI hate to be pitiful.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText:
You will find,
however, Miss Morland, it would be reckoned a cheap thing by some
people, for I might have sold it for ten guineas more the next day;
Jackson, of Oriel, bid me sixty at once; Morland was with me at the
time.
subQuotationList:
['You will find,
however, Miss Morland, it would be reckoned a cheap thing by some
people, for I might have sold it for ten guineas more the next day;
Jackson, of Oriel, bid me sixty at once; Morland was with me at the
time.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText:
Yes, but you forget that your
horse was included.
subQuotationList: ['Yes,', 'but you forget that your\nhorse was included.']
speaker: James Morland

quoteText:
My horse! Oh, d   it! I would not sell my horse for a hundred. Are you
fond of an open carriage, Miss Morland?
subQuotationList: ['My horse! Oh, d   it! I would not sell my horse for a hundred. Are you\nfond of an open carriage, Miss Morland?']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText:
Yes, very; I have hardly ever an opportunity of being in one; but I am
particularly fond of it.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, very; I have hardly ever an opportunity of being in one; but I am\nparticularly fond of it.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: I am glad of it; I will drive you out in mine every day.
subQuotationList: ['I am glad of it; I will drive you out in mine every day.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText: Thank you,
subQuotationList: ['Thank you,']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: I will drive you up Lansdown Hill tomorrow.
subQuotationList: ['I will drive you up Lansdown Hill tomorrow.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText: Thank you; but will not your horse want rest?
subQuotationList: ['Thank you; but will not your horse want rest?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Rest! He has only come three and twenty miles today; all nonsense;
nothing ruins horses so much as rest; nothing knocks them up so soon.
No, no; I shall exercise mine at the average of four hours every day
while I am here.
subQuotationList:
['Rest! He has only come three and twenty miles today; all nonsense;
nothing ruins horses so much as rest; nothing knocks them up so soon.
No, no; I shall exercise mine at the average of four hours every day
while I am here.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText:
Shall you indeed! That will be forty
miles a day.
subQuotationList: ['Shall you indeed!', 'That will be forty\nmiles a day.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Forty! Aye, fifty, for what I care. Well, I will drive you up Lansdown
tomorrow; mind, I am engaged.
subQuotationList: ['Forty! Aye, fifty, for what I care. Well, I will drive you up Lansdown\ntomorrow; mind, I am engaged.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText:
How delightful that will be! My
dearest Catherine, I quite envy you; but I am afraid, brother, you will
not have room for a third.
subQuotationList: ['How delightful that will be!', 'My\ndearest Catherine, I quite envy you; but I am afraid, brother, you will\nnot have room for a third.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe

quoteText:
A third indeed! No, no; I did not come to Bath to drive my sisters
about; that would be a good joke, faith! Morland must take care of
you.
subQuotationList: ['A third indeed! No, no; I did not come to Bath to drive my sisters\nabout; that would be a good joke, faith! Morland must take care of\nyou.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText:
Have you ever
read Udolpho, Mr. Thorpe?
subQuotationList: ['Have you ever\nread Udolpho, Mr. Thorpe?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Udolpho! Oh, Lord! Not I; I never read novels; I have something else
to do.
subQuotationList: ['Udolpho! Oh, Lord! Not I; I never read novels; I have something else\nto do.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText:
Novels are all so full of
nonsense and stuff; there has not been a tolerably decent one come out
since Tom Jones, except The Monk; I read that t other day; but as for
all the others, they are the stupidest things in creation.
subQuotationList:
['Novels are all so full of
nonsense and stuff; there has not been a tolerably decent one come out
since Tom Jones, except The Monk; I read that t other day; but as for
all the others, they are the stupidest things in creation.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText:
I think you must like Udolpho, if you were to read it; it is so very
interesting.
subQuotationList: ['I think you must like Udolpho, if you were to read it; it is so very\ninteresting.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Not I, faith! No, if I read any, it shall be Mrs. Radcliffe s; her
novels are amusing enough; they are worth reading; some fun and nature
in _them_.
subQuotationList: ['Not I, faith! No, if I read any, it shall be Mrs. Radcliffe s; her\nnovels are amusing enough; they are worth reading; some fun and nature\nin _them_.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText: Udolpho was written by Mrs. Radcliffe,
subQuotationList: ['Udolpho was written by Mrs. Radcliffe,']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
No sure; was it? Aye, I remember, so it was; I was thinking of that
other stupid book, written by that woman they make such a fuss about,
she who married the French emigrant.
subQuotationList: ['No sure; was it? Aye, I remember, so it was; I was thinking of that\nother stupid book, written by that woman they make such a fuss about,\nshe who married the French emigrant.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText: I suppose you mean Camilla?
subQuotationList: ['I suppose you mean Camilla?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Yes, that s the book; such unnatural stuff! An old man playing at
see-saw, I took up the first volume once and looked it over, but I soon
found it would not do; indeed I guessed what sort of stuff it must be
before I saw it: as soon as I heard she had married an emigrant, I was
sure I should never be able to get through it.
subQuotationList:
['Yes, that s the book; such unnatural stuff! An old man playing at
see-saw, I took up the first volume once and looked it over, but I soon
found it would not do; indeed I guessed what sort of stuff it must be
before I saw it: as soon as I heard she had married an emigrant, I was
sure I should never be able to get through it.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText: I have never read it.
subQuotationList: ['I have never read it.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
You had no loss, I assure you; it is the horridest nonsense you can
imagine; there is nothing in the world in it but an old man s playing
at see-saw and learning Latin; upon my soul there is not.
subQuotationList: ['You had no loss, I assure you; it is the horridest nonsense you can\nimagine; there is nothing in the world in it but an old man s playing\nat see-saw and learning Latin; upon my soul there is not.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText:
Ah, Mother!
How do you do? Where
did you get that quiz of a hat? It makes you look like an old witch.
Here is Morland and I come to stay a few days with you, so you must
look out for a couple of good beds somewhere near.
subQuotationList:
['Ah, Mother!
How do you do?', 'Where
did you get that quiz of a hat? It makes you look like an old witch.
Here is Morland and I come to stay a few days with you, so you must
look out for a couple of good beds somewhere near.']
speaker: John Thorpe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Thorpe'], ['Mrs. Thorpe']], [['Mrs. Thorpe'], ['Mrs. Thorpe'], ['James Morland'], ['Mrs. Thorpe'], ['Mrs. Thorpe']]]

quoteText:
Well, Catherine, how do you like my
friend Thorpe?
subQuotationList: ['Well, Catherine, how do you like my\nfriend Thorpe?']
speaker: James Morland
referringExpression: James as the door was closed on them said

quoteText:
I like him very much; he seems
very agreeable.
subQuotationList: ['I like him very much; he seems\nvery agreeable.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

subQuotationList: ['He is as good-natured a fellow as ever lived; a little of a rattle;\nbut that will recommend him to your sex, I believe: and how do you like\nthe rest of the family?']
speaker: James Morland

quoteText: Very, very much indeed: Isabella particularly.
subQuotationList: ['Very, very much indeed: Isabella particularly.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
I am very glad to hear you say so; she is just the kind of young woman
I could wish to see you attached to; she has so much good sense, and is
so thoroughly unaffected and amiable; I always wanted you to know her;
and she seems very fond of you. She said the highest things in your
praise that could possibly be; and the praise of such a girl as Miss
Thorpe even you, Catherine,
subQuotationList:
['I am very glad to hear you say so; she is just the kind of young woman
I could wish to see you attached to; she has so much good sense, and is
so thoroughly unaffected and amiable; I always wanted you to know her;
and she seems very fond of you. She said the highest things in your
praise that could possibly be; and the praise of such a girl as Miss
Thorpe even you, Catherine,']
speaker: James Morland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Catherine Morland'], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText:
may be
proud of.
subQuotationList: ['may be\nproud of.']
speaker: James Morland

quoteText:
Indeed I am, I love her exceedingly, and am delighted
to find that you like her too. You hardly mentioned anything of her
when you wrote to me after your visit there.
subQuotationList: ['Indeed I am,', 'I love her exceedingly, and am delighted\nto find that you like her too. You hardly mentioned anything of her\nwhen you wrote to me after your visit there.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Because I thought I should soon see you myself. I hope you will be a
great deal together while you are in Bath. She is a most amiable girl;
such a superior understanding! How fond all the family are of her; she
is evidently the general favourite; and how much she must be admired in
such a place as this is not she?
subQuotationList:
['Because I thought I should soon see you myself. I hope you will be a
great deal together while you are in Bath. She is a most amiable girl;
such a superior understanding! How fond all the family are of her; she
is evidently the general favourite; and how much she must be admired in
such a place as this is not she?']
speaker: James Morland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Mr. Thorpe', 'Mrs. Thorpe', 'Isabella Thorpe', 'John Thorpe'], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Isabella Thorpe']]]

quoteText:
Yes, very much indeed, I fancy; Mr. Allen thinks her the prettiest
girl in Bath.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, very much indeed, I fancy; Mr. Allen thinks her the prettiest\ngirl in Bath.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
I dare say he does; and I do not know any man who is a better judge of
beauty than Mr. Allen. I need not ask you whether you are happy here,
my dear Catherine; with such a companion and friend as Isabella Thorpe,
it would be impossible for you to be otherwise; and the Allens, I am
sure, are very kind to you?
subQuotationList:
['I dare say he does; and I do not know any man who is a better judge of
beauty than Mr. Allen. I need not ask you whether you are happy here,
my dear Catherine; with such a companion and friend as Isabella Thorpe,
it would be impossible for you to be otherwise; and the Allens, I am
sure, are very kind to you?']
speaker: James Morland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Allen'], ['Mr. Allen'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Mrs. Allen', 'Mr. Allen'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText:
Yes, very kind; I never was so happy before; and now you are come it
will be more delightful than ever; how good it is of you to come so far
on purpose to see _me_.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, very kind; I never was so happy before; and now you are come it\nwill be more delightful than ever; how good it is of you to come so far\non purpose to see _me_.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Indeed,
Catherine, I love you dearly.
subQuotationList: ['Indeed,\nCatherine, I love you dearly.']
speaker: James Morland
referringExpression: James accepted this tribute of gratitude and qualified his conscience for accepting it too by saying

quoteText:
I assure you, I would not stand up without your dear
sister for all the world; for if I did we should certainly be separated
the whole evening.
subQuotationList: ['I assure you,', 'I would not stand up without your dear\nsister for all the world; for if I did we should certainly be separated\nthe whole evening.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe

quoteText:
My dear creature, I am
afraid I must leave you, your brother is so amazingly impatient to
begin; I know you will not mind my going away, and I dare say John will
be back in a moment, and then you may easily find me out.
subQuotationList:
['My dear creature, I am
afraid I must leave you, your brother is so amazingly impatient to
begin; I know you will not mind my going away, and I dare say John will
be back in a moment, and then you may easily find me out.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe
referringExpression: Isabella who had been talking to James on the other side of her turned again to his sister and whispered
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['James Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['John Thorpe'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText: Good-bye, my dear love,
subQuotationList: ['Good-bye, my dear love,']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe
referringExpression: Isabella had only time to press her friend s hand and say

quoteText:
I am very happy to see you again, sir, indeed; I was afraid you had
left Bath.
subQuotationList: ['I am very happy to see you again, sir, indeed; I was afraid you had\nleft Bath.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Well, sir, and I dare say you are not sorry to be back again, for it
is just the place for young people and indeed for everybody else too. I
tell Mr. Allen, when he talks of being sick of it, that I am sure he
should not complain, for it is so very agreeable a place, that it is
much better to be here than at home at this dull time of year. I tell
him he is quite in luck to be sent here for his health.
subQuotationList:
['Well, sir, and I dare say you are not sorry to be back again, for it
is just the place for young people and indeed for everybody else too. I
tell Mr. Allen, when he talks of being sick of it, that I am sure he
should not complain, for it is so very agreeable a place, that it is
much better to be here than at home at this dull time of year. I tell
him he is quite in luck to be sent here for his health.']
speaker: Mrs. Allen
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Henry Tilney'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Mr. Allen'], ['Mr. Allen'], ['Mr. Allen'], ['Mr. Allen'], ['Mr. Allen'], ['Mr. Allen']]]

quoteText:
And I hope, madam, that Mr. Allen will be obliged to like the place,
from finding it of service to him.
subQuotationList: ['And I hope, madam, that Mr. Allen will be obliged to like the place,\nfrom finding it of service to him.']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText:
Thank you, sir. I have no doubt that he will. A neighbour of ours, Dr.
Skinner, was here for his health last winter, and came away quite
stout.
subQuotationList: ['Thank you, sir. I have no doubt that he will. A neighbour of ours, Dr.\nSkinner, was here for his health last winter, and came away quite\nstout.']
speaker: Mrs. Allen

quoteText: That circumstance must give great encouragement.
subQuotationList: ['That circumstance must give great encouragement.']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText:
Yes, sir and Dr. Skinner and his family were here three months; so I
tell Mr. Allen he must not be in a hurry to get away.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, sir and Dr. Skinner and his family were here three months; so I\ntell Mr. Allen he must not be in a hurry to get away.']
speaker: Mrs. Allen

quoteText:
I beg
your pardon, Miss Morland, for this liberty but I cannot
anyhow get to Miss Thorpe, and Mrs. Thorpe said she was sure you would
not have the least objection to letting in this young lady by you.
subQuotationList:
['I beg
your pardon, Miss Morland,', 'for this liberty but I cannot
anyhow get to Miss Thorpe, and Mrs. Thorpe said she was sure you would
not have the least objection to letting in this young lady by you.']
speaker: Mrs. Hughes
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland']], [['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Mrs. Thorpe'], ['Mrs. Thorpe'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Eleanor Tilney'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText:
At last I have got you. My dearest creature, I have been looking for
you this hour. What could induce you to come into this set, when you
knew I was in the other? I have been quite wretched without you.
subQuotationList: ['At last I have got you. My dearest creature, I have been looking for\nyou this hour. What could induce you to come into this set, when you\nknew I was in the other? I have been quite wretched without you.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe
referringExpression: Isabella who in great spirits exclaimed
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText:
My dear Isabella, how was it possible for me to get at you? I could
not even see where you were.
subQuotationList: ['My dear Isabella, how was it possible for me to get at you? I could\nnot even see where you were.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
So I told your brother all the time but he would not believe me. Do go
and see for her, Mr. Morland, said I but all in vain he would not stir
an inch. Was not it so, Mr. Morland? But you men are all so
immoderately lazy! I have been scolding him to such a degree, my dear
Catherine, you would be quite amazed. You know I never stand upon
ceremony with such people.
subQuotationList:
['So I told your brother all the time but he would not believe me. Do go
and see for her, Mr. Morland, said I but all in vain he would not stir
an inch. Was not it so, Mr. Morland? But you men are all so
immoderately lazy! I have been scolding him to such a degree, my dear
Catherine, you would be quite amazed. You know I never stand upon
ceremony with such people.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['James Morland'], ['James Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['James Morland'], ['James Morland'], ['James Morland'], ['James Morland'], ['James Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText:
Look at that young lady with the white beads round her head, It is Mr.
Tilney s sister.
subQuotationList: ['Look at that young lady with the white beads round her head,', 'It is Mr.\nTilney s sister.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Oh! Heavens! You don t say so! Let me look at her this moment. What a
delightful girl! I never saw anything half so beautiful! But where is
her all-conquering brother? Is he in the room? Point him out to me this
instant, if he is. I die to see him. Mr. Morland, you are not to
listen. We are not talking about you.
subQuotationList:
['Oh! Heavens! You don t say so! Let me look at her this moment. What a
delightful girl! I never saw anything half so beautiful! But where is
her all-conquering brother? Is he in the room? Point him out to me this
instant, if he is. I die to see him. Mr. Morland, you are not to
listen. We are not talking about you.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Catherine Morland'], ['Eleanor Tilney'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['James Morland'], ['James Morland'], ['Isabella Thorpe', 'Catherine Morland'], ['James Morland']]]

quoteText: But what is all this whispering about? What is going on?
subQuotationList: ['But what is all this whispering about? What is going on?']
speaker: James Morland

quoteText:
There now, I knew how it would be. You men have such restless
curiosity! Talk of the curiosity of women, indeed!  Tis nothing. But be
satisfied, for you are not to know anything at all of the matter.
subQuotationList: ['There now, I knew how it would be. You men have such restless\ncuriosity! Talk of the curiosity of women, indeed!  Tis nothing. But be\nsatisfied, for you are not to know anything at all of the matter.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe

quoteText: And is that likely to satisfy me, do you think?
subQuotationList: ['And is that likely to satisfy me, do you think?']
speaker: James Morland

quoteText:
Well, I declare I never knew anything like you. What can it signify to
you, what we are talking of. Perhaps we are talking about you;
therefore I would advise you not to listen, or you may happen to hear
something not very agreeable.
subQuotationList:
['Well, I declare I never knew anything like you. What can it signify to
you, what we are talking of. Perhaps we are talking about you;
therefore I would advise you not to listen, or you may happen to hear
something not very agreeable.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['James Morland'], ['Isabella Thorpe', 'Catherine Morland'], ['Isabella Thorpe', 'Catherine Morland'], ['James Morland'], ['James Morland'], ['James Morland']]]

quoteText:
I tell you, Mr.
Morland, I would not do such a thing for all the world.
How can you be so teasing; only conceive, my dear Catherine, what your
brother wants me to do. He wants me to dance with him again, though I
tell him that it is a most improper thing, and entirely against the
rules. It would make us the talk of the place, if we were not to change
partners.
subQuotationList:
['I tell you, Mr.
Morland,', 'I would not do such a thing for all the world.
How can you be so teasing; only conceive, my dear Catherine, what your
brother wants me to do. He wants me to dance with him again, though I
tell him that it is a most improper thing, and entirely against the
rules. It would make us the talk of the place, if we were not to change
partners.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['James Morland'], ['James Morland']], [['James Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['James Morland'], ['James Morland'], ['James Morland'], ['James Morland'], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Isabella Thorpe']]]

quoteText:
Upon my honour, in these public assemblies, it is as
often done as not.
subQuotationList: ['Upon my honour,', 'in these public assemblies, it is as\noften done as not.']
speaker: James Morland

quoteText:
Nonsense, how can you say so? But when you men have a point to carry,
you never stick at anything. My sweet Catherine, do support me;
persuade your brother how impossible it is. Tell him that it would
quite shock you to see me do such a thing; now would not it?
subQuotationList:
['Nonsense, how can you say so? But when you men have a point to carry,
you never stick at anything. My sweet Catherine, do support me;
persuade your brother how impossible it is. Tell him that it would
quite shock you to see me do such a thing; now would not it?']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['James Morland'], ['James Morland'], ['James Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['James Morland'], ['James Morland'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText:
No, not at all; but if you think it wrong, you had much better
change.
subQuotationList: ['No, not at all; but if you think it wrong, you had much better\nchange.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
There, you hear what your sister says, and yet you
will not mind her. Well, remember that it is not my fault, if we set
all the old ladies in Bath in a bustle. Come along, my dearest
Catherine, for heaven s sake, and stand by me.
subQuotationList:
['There,', 'you hear what your sister says, and yet you
will not mind her. Well, remember that it is not my fault, if we set
all the old ladies in Bath in a bustle. Come along, my dearest
Catherine, for heaven s sake, and stand by me.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['James Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['James Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText:
Well, my dear, I hope you have had
an agreeable partner.
subQuotationList: ['Well, my dear,', 'I hope you have had\nan agreeable partner.']
speaker: Mrs. Thorpe

quoteText: Very agreeable, madam.
subQuotationList: ['Very agreeable, madam.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: I am glad of it. John has charming spirits, has not he?
subQuotationList: ['I am glad of it. John has charming spirits, has not he?']
speaker: Mrs. Thorpe

quoteText: Did you meet Mr. Tilney, my dear?
subQuotationList: ['Did you meet Mr. Tilney, my dear?']
speaker: Mrs. Allen

quoteText: No, where is he?
subQuotationList: ['No, where is he?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
He was with us just now, and said he was so tired of lounging about,
that he was resolved to go and dance; so I thought perhaps he would ask
you, if he met with you.
subQuotationList: ['He was with us just now, and said he was so tired of lounging about,\nthat he was resolved to go and dance; so I thought perhaps he would ask\nyou, if he met with you.']
speaker: Mrs. Allen
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Henry Tilney'], ['Mrs. Thorpe', 'Mrs. Allen'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText: Where can he be?
subQuotationList: ['Where can he be?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: Ah! He has got a partner; I wish he had asked _you_,
subQuotationList: ['Ah! He has got a partner; I wish he had asked _you_,']
speaker: Mrs. Allen

quoteText:
he is a very agreeable young
man.
subQuotationList: ['he is a very agreeable young\nman.']
speaker: Mrs. Allen

quoteText:
Indeed he is, Mrs. Allen, I
must say it, though I _am_ his mother, that there is not a more
agreeable young man in the world.
subQuotationList: ['Indeed he is, Mrs. Allen,', 'I\nmust say it, though I _am_ his mother, that there is not a more\nagreeable young man in the world.']
speaker: Mrs. Thorpe

quoteText:
I dare say she
thought I was speaking of her son.
subQuotationList: ['I dare say she\nthought I was speaking of her son.']
speaker: Mrs. Allen
referringExpression: she said in a whisper to Catherine

quoteText:
Well, Miss Morland, I suppose you and I are
to stand up and jig it together again.
subQuotationList: ['Well, Miss Morland, I suppose you and I are\nto stand up and jig it together again.']
speaker: John Thorpe
referringExpression: John Thorpe came up to her soon afterwards and said

quoteText:
Oh, no; I am much obliged to you, our two dances are over; and,
besides, I am tired, and do not mean to dance any more.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, no; I am much obliged to you, our two dances are over; and,\nbesides, I am tired, and do not mean to dance any more.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Do not you? Then let us walk about and quiz people. Come along with
me, and I will show you the four greatest quizzers in the room; my two
younger sisters and their partners. I have been laughing at them this
half hour.
subQuotationList:
['Do not you? Then let us walk about and quiz people. Come along with
me, and I will show you the four greatest quizzers in the room; my two
younger sisters and their partners. I have been laughing at them this
half hour.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText: dearest Catherine.
subQuotationList: ['dearest Catherine.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe
referringExpression: the latter had no leisure to bestow more on her friend

quoteText:
Well, Miss Morland, here I am. Have you
been waiting long? We could not come before; the old devil of a
coachmaker was such an eternity finding out a thing fit to be got into,
and now it is ten thousand to one but they break down before we are out
of the street. How do you do, Mrs. Allen? A famous ball last night, was
not it? Come, Miss Morland, be quick, for the others are in a
confounded hurry to be off. They want to get their tumble over.
subQuotationList:
['Well, Miss Morland, here I am. Have you
been waiting long? We could not come before; the old devil of a
coachmaker was such an eternity finding out a thing fit to be got into,
and now it is ten thousand to one but they break down before we are out
of the street. How do you do, Mrs. Allen? A famous ball last night, was
not it? Come, Miss Morland, be quick, for the others are in a
confounded hurry to be off. They want to get their tumble over.']
speaker: John Thorpe
referringExpression: John Thorpe came running upstairs calling out
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['James Morland', 'John Thorpe', 'Isabella Thorpe'], ['James Morland', 'John Thorpe', 'Isabella Thorpe'], ['Mrs. Allen'], ['Mrs. Allen'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['James Morland', 'Isabella Thorpe'], ['James Morland', 'Isabella Thorpe']]]

quoteText: What do you mean? Where are you all going to?
subQuotationList: ['What do you mean?', 'Where are you all going to?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Going to? Why, you have not forgot our engagement! Did not we agree
together to take a drive this morning? What a head you have! We are
going up Claverton Down.
subQuotationList: ['Going to? Why, you have not forgot our engagement! Did not we agree\ntogether to take a drive this morning? What a head you have! We are\ngoing up Claverton Down.']
speaker: John Thorpe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Catherine Morland'], ['John Thorpe', 'Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland', 'James Morland', 'Isabella Thorpe', 'John Thorpe']]]

quoteText: Something was said about it, I remember, but really I did not expect you.
subQuotationList: ['Something was said about it, I remember,', 'but really I did not expect you.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Not expect me! That s a good one! And what a dust you would have made,
if I had not come.
subQuotationList: ['Not expect me! That s a good one! And what a dust you would have made,\nif I had not come.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText:
Well, ma am, what do you say to it? Can you
spare me for an hour or two? Shall I go?
subQuotationList: ['Well, ma am, what do you say to it? Can you\nspare me for an hour or two? Shall I go?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: Do just as you please, my dear,
subQuotationList: ['Do just as you please, my dear,']
speaker: Mrs. Allen

quoteText:
My dearest creature, you have been at least three hours getting ready. I was
afraid you were ill. What a delightful ball we had last night. I have a
thousand things to say to you; but make haste and get in, for I long to
be off.
subQuotationList:
['My dearest creature,', 'you have been at least three hours getting ready. I was
afraid you were ill. What a delightful ball we had last night. I have a
thousand things to say to you; but make haste and get in, for I long to
be off.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Catherine Morland']], [['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland', 'Isabella Thorpe', 'James Morland', 'John Thorpe'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText:
What a sweet girl she is! I quite
dote on her.
subQuotationList: ['What a sweet girl she is! I quite\ndote on her.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe
referringExpression: her friend exclaim aloud to James

quoteText:
