You will not be frightened, Miss Morland, if my horse should dance about a little at first setting off.
He will, most likely, give a plunge or two, and perhaps take the rest
for a minute; but he will soon know his master. He is full of spirits,
playful as can be, but there is no vice in him.
subQuotationList:
['You will not be frightened, Miss Morland,', 'if my horse should dance about a little at first setting off.
He will, most likely, give a plunge or two, and perhaps take the rest
for a minute; but he will soon know his master. He is full of spirits,
playful as can be, but there is no vice in him.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText:
Old Allen is as rich as a Jew is not
he?
subQuotationList: ['Old Allen is as rich as a Jew is not\nhe?']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText: Old Allen, the man you are with.
subQuotationList: ['Old Allen, the man you are with.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText: Oh! Mr. Allen, you mean. Yes, I believe, he is very rich.
subQuotationList: ['Oh! Mr. Allen, you mean. Yes, I believe, he is very rich.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: And no children at all?
subQuotationList: ['And no children at all?']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText: No not any.
subQuotationList: ['No not any.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: A famous thing for his next heirs. He is _your_ godfather, is not he?
subQuotationList: ['A famous thing for his next heirs. He is _your_ godfather, is not he?']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText: My godfather! No.
subQuotationList: ['My godfather! No.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: But you are always very much with them.
subQuotationList: ['But you are always very much with them.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText: Yes, very much.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, very much.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Aye, that is what I meant. He seems a good kind of old fellow enough,
and has lived very well in his time, I dare say; he is not gouty for
nothing. Does he drink his bottle a day now?
subQuotationList: ['Aye, that is what I meant. He seems a good kind of old fellow enough,\nand has lived very well in his time, I dare say; he is not gouty for\nnothing. Does he drink his bottle a day now?']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText:
His bottle a day! No. Why should you think of such a thing? He is a
very temperate man, and you could not fancy him in liquor last night?
subQuotationList: ['His bottle a day! No. Why should you think of such a thing? He is a\nvery temperate man, and you could not fancy him in liquor last night?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Lord help you! You women are always thinking of men s being in liquor.
Why, you do not suppose a man is overset by a bottle? I am sure of
_this_ that if everybody was to drink their bottle a day, there would
not be half the disorders in the world there are now. It would be a
famous good thing for us all.
subQuotationList:
['Lord help you! You women are always thinking of men s being in liquor.
Why, you do not suppose a man is overset by a bottle? I am sure of
_this_ that if everybody was to drink their bottle a day, there would
not be half the disorders in the world there are now. It would be a
famous good thing for us all.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText: I cannot believe it.
subQuotationList: ['I cannot believe it.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Oh! Lord, it would be the saving of thousands. There is not the
hundredth part of the wine consumed in this kingdom that there ought to
be. Our foggy climate wants help.
subQuotationList: ['Oh! Lord, it would be the saving of thousands. There is not the\nhundredth part of the wine consumed in this kingdom that there ought to\nbe. Our foggy climate wants help.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText:
And yet I have heard that there is a great deal of wine drunk in
Oxford.
subQuotationList: ['And yet I have heard that there is a great deal of wine drunk in\nOxford.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Oxford! There is no drinking at Oxford now, I assure you. Nobody
drinks there. You would hardly meet with a man who goes beyond his four
pints at the utmost. Now, for instance, it was reckoned a remarkable
thing, at the last party in my rooms, that upon an average we cleared
about five pints a head. It was looked upon as something out of the
common way. _Mine_ is famous good stuff, to be sure. You would not
often meet with anything like it in Oxford and that may account for it.
But this will just give you a notion of the general rate of drinking
there.
subQuotationList:
['Oxford! There is no drinking at Oxford now, I assure you. Nobody
drinks there. You would hardly meet with a man who goes beyond his four
pints at the utmost. Now, for instance, it was reckoned a remarkable
thing, at the last party in my rooms, that upon an average we cleared
about five pints a head. It was looked upon as something out of the
common way. _Mine_ is famous good stuff, to be sure. You would not
often meet with anything like it in Oxford and that may account for it.
But this will just give you a notion of the general rate of drinking
there.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText:
Yes, it does give a notion, and that is, that
you all drink a great deal more wine than I thought you did. However, I
am sure James does not drink so much. You do not really
think, Mr. Thorpe, that James s gig will break down?
subQuotationList:
['Yes, it does give a notion,', 'and that is, that
you all drink a great deal more wine than I thought you did. However, I
am sure James does not drink so much.', 'You do not really
think, Mr. Thorpe,', 'that James s gig will break down?']
speaker: Catherine Morland
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['John Thorpe'], ['John Thorpe'], ['James Morland']], [['John Thorpe'], ['John Thorpe']], [['James Morland']]]

quoteText:
Break down! Oh! Lord! Did you ever see such a little tittuppy thing in
your life? There is not a sound piece of iron about it. The wheels have
been fairly worn out these ten years at least and as for the body! Upon
my soul, you might shake it to pieces yourself with a touch. It is the
most devilish little rickety business I ever beheld! Thank God! we have
got a better. I would not be bound to go two miles in it for fifty
thousand pounds.
subQuotationList:
['Break down! Oh! Lord! Did you ever see such a little tittuppy thing in
your life? There is not a sound piece of iron about it. The wheels have
been fairly worn out these ten years at least and as for the body! Upon
my soul, you might shake it to pieces yourself with a touch. It is the
most devilish little rickety business I ever beheld! Thank God! we have
got a better. I would not be bound to go two miles in it for fifty
thousand pounds.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText:
Good heavens! Then pray let us
turn back; they will certainly meet with an accident if we go on. Do
let us turn back, Mr. Thorpe; stop and speak to my brother, and tell
him how very unsafe it is.
subQuotationList:
['Good heavens!', 'Then pray let us
turn back; they will certainly meet with an accident if we go on. Do
let us turn back, Mr. Thorpe; stop and speak to my brother, and tell
him how very unsafe it is.']
speaker: Catherine Morland
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['John Thorpe', 'Catherine Morland'], ['James Morland', 'Isabella Thorpe'], ['James Morland', 'Isabella Thorpe', 'John Thorpe', 'Catherine Morland'], ['John Thorpe', 'Catherine Morland'], ['John Thorpe'], ['James Morland'], ['James Morland']]]

quoteText:
Unsafe! Oh, lord! What is there in that? They will only get a roll if
it does break down; and there is plenty of dirt; it will be excellent
falling. Oh, curse it! The carriage is safe enough, if a man knows how
to drive it; a thing of that sort in good hands will last above twenty
years after it is fairly worn out. Lord bless you! I would undertake
for five pounds to drive it to York and back again, without losing a
nail.
subQuotationList:
['Unsafe! Oh, lord! What is there in that? They will only get a roll if
it does break down; and there is plenty of dirt; it will be excellent
falling. Oh, curse it! The carriage is safe enough, if a man knows how
to drive it; a thing of that sort in good hands will last above twenty
years after it is fairly worn out. Lord bless you! I would undertake
for five pounds to drive it to York and back again, without losing a
nail.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText: Past three o clock!
subQuotationList: ['Past three o clock!']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe

quoteText:
Well, my dear, here you
are, and I hope you have had a pleasant airing?
subQuotationList: ['Well, my dear, here you\nare,', 'and I hope you have had a pleasant airing?']
speaker: Mrs. Allen
referringExpression: Catherine found Mrs Allen just returned from all the busy idleness of the morning and was immediately greeted

quoteText: Yes, ma am, I thank you; we could not have had a nicer day.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, ma am, I thank you; we could not have had a nicer day.']
speaker: Catherine Morland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Allen'], ['Mrs. Allen'], ['James Morland', 'Isabella Thorpe', 'John Thorpe', 'Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText: So Mrs. Thorpe said; she was vastly pleased at your all going.
subQuotationList: ['So Mrs. Thorpe said; she was vastly pleased at your all going.']
speaker: Mrs. Allen
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Thorpe'], ['Mrs. Thorpe'], ['James Morland', 'John Thorpe', 'Isabella Thorpe', 'Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText: You have seen Mrs. Thorpe, then?
subQuotationList: ['You have seen Mrs. Thorpe, then?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Yes, I went to the pump-room as soon as you were gone, and there I met
her, and we had a great deal of talk together. She says there was
hardly any veal to be got at market this morning, it is so uncommonly
scarce.
subQuotationList:
['Yes, I went to the pump-room as soon as you were gone, and there I met
her, and we had a great deal of talk together. She says there was
hardly any veal to be got at market this morning, it is so uncommonly
scarce.']
speaker: Mrs. Allen

quoteText: Did you see anybody else of our acquaintance?
subQuotationList: ['Did you see anybody else of our acquaintance?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Yes; we agreed to take a turn in the Crescent, and there we met Mrs.
Hughes, and Mr. and Miss Tilney walking with her.
subQuotationList: ['Yes; we agreed to take a turn in the Crescent, and there we met Mrs.\nHughes, and Mr. and Miss Tilney walking with her.']
speaker: Mrs. Allen
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Thorpe', 'Mrs. Allen'], ['Mrs. Thorpe', 'Mrs. Allen'], ['Mrs. Hughes'], ['Henry Tilney', 'Eleanor Tilney'], ['Mrs. Hughes']]]

quoteText: Did you indeed? And did they speak to you?
subQuotationList: ['Did you indeed? And did they speak to you?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Yes, we walked along the Crescent together for half an hour. They seem
very agreeable people. Miss Tilney was in a very pretty spotted muslin,
and I fancy, by what I can learn, that she always dresses very
handsomely. Mrs. Hughes talked to me a great deal about the family.
subQuotationList:
['Yes, we walked along the Crescent together for half an hour. They seem
very agreeable people. Miss Tilney was in a very pretty spotted muslin,
and I fancy, by what I can learn, that she always dresses very
handsomely. Mrs. Hughes talked to me a great deal about the family.']
speaker: Mrs. Allen
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Henry Tilney', 'Mrs. Thorpe', 'Eleanor Tilney', 'Mrs. Allen', 'Mrs. Hughes'], ['Henry Tilney', 'Eleanor Tilney', 'Mrs. Hughes'], ['Eleanor Tilney'], ['Eleanor Tilney'], ['Mrs. Hughes'], ['Henry Tilney', 'Eleanor Tilney']]]

quoteText: And what did she tell you of them?
subQuotationList: ['And what did she tell you of them?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: Oh! A vast deal indeed; she hardly talked of anything else.
subQuotationList: ['Oh! A vast deal indeed; she hardly talked of anything else.']
speaker: Mrs. Allen

quoteText: Did she tell you what part of Gloucestershire they come from?
subQuotationList: ['Did she tell you what part of Gloucestershire they come from?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Yes, she did; but I cannot recollect now. But they are very good kind
of people, and very rich. Mrs. Tilney was a Miss Drummond, and she and
Mrs. Hughes were schoolfellows; and Miss Drummond had a very large
fortune; and, when she married, her father gave her twenty thousand
pounds, and five hundred to buy wedding-clothes. Mrs. Hughes saw all
the clothes after they came from the warehouse.
subQuotationList:
['Yes, she did; but I cannot recollect now. But they are very good kind
of people, and very rich. Mrs. Tilney was a Miss Drummond, and she and
Mrs. Hughes were schoolfellows; and Miss Drummond had a very large
fortune; and, when she married, her father gave her twenty thousand
pounds, and five hundred to buy wedding-clothes. Mrs. Hughes saw all
the clothes after they came from the warehouse.']
speaker: Mrs. Allen

quoteText: And are Mr. and Mrs. Tilney in Bath?
subQuotationList: ['And are Mr. and Mrs. Tilney in Bath?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Yes, I fancy they are, but I am not quite certain. Upon recollection,
however, I have a notion they are both dead; at least the mother is;
yes, I am sure Mrs. Tilney is dead, because Mrs. Hughes told me there
was a very beautiful set of pearls that Mr. Drummond gave his daughter
on her wedding-day and that Miss Tilney has got now, for they were put
by for her when her mother died.
subQuotationList:
['Yes, I fancy they are, but I am not quite certain. Upon recollection,
however, I have a notion they are both dead; at least the mother is;
yes, I am sure Mrs. Tilney is dead, because Mrs. Hughes told me there
was a very beautiful set of pearls that Mr. Drummond gave his daughter
on her wedding-day and that Miss Tilney has got now, for they were put
by for her when her mother died.']
speaker: Mrs. Allen

quoteText: And is Mr. Tilney, my partner, the only son?
subQuotationList: ['And is Mr. Tilney, my partner, the only son?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
I cannot be quite positive about that, my dear; I have some idea he
is; but, however, he is a very fine young man, Mrs. Hughes says, and
likely to do very well.
subQuotationList: ['I cannot be quite positive about that, my dear; I have some idea he\nis; but, however, he is a very fine young man, Mrs. Hughes says, and\nlikely to do very well.']
speaker: Mrs. Allen

quoteText:
Oh, heavens! My
beloved Catherine, have I got you at last? Now, Mr. Morland, I shall not speak another
word to you all the rest of the evening; so I charge you not to expect
it. My sweetest Catherine, how have you been this long age? But I need
not ask you, for you look delightfully. You really have done your hair
in a more heavenly style than ever; you mischievous creature, do you
want to attract everybody? I assure you, my brother is quite in love
with you already; and as for Mr. Tilney but _that_ is a settled
thing even _your_ modesty cannot doubt his attachment now; his coming
back to Bath makes it too plain. Oh! What would not I give to see him!
I really am quite wild with impatience. My mother says he is the most
delightful young man in the world; she saw him this morning, you know;
you must introduce him to me. Is he in the house now? Look about, for
heaven s sake! I assure you, I can hardly exist till I see him.
subQuotationList:
['Oh, heavens! My
beloved Catherine, have I got you at last?', 'Now, Mr. Morland,', 'I shall not speak another
word to you all the rest of the evening; so I charge you not to expect
it. My sweetest Catherine, how have you been this long age? But I need
not ask you, for you look delightfully. You really have done your hair
in a more heavenly style than ever; you mischievous creature, do you
want to attract everybody? I assure you, my brother is quite in love
with you already; and as for Mr. Tilney but _that_ is a settled
thing even _your_ modesty cannot doubt his attachment now; his coming
back to Bath makes it too plain. Oh! What would not I give to see him!
I really am quite wild with impatience. My mother says he is the most
delightful young man in the world; she saw him this morning, you know;
you must introduce him to me. Is he in the house now? Look about, for
heaven s sake! I assure you, I can hardly exist till I see him.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe
mentionTextsList: [['My\nbeloved Catherine', 'you'], ['Mr. Morland'], ['you', 'you', 'My sweetest Catherine', 'you', 'you', 'you', 'You', 'you mischievous creature', 'you', 'you', 'my brother', 'you', 'Mr. Tilney', 'your', 'his', 'his', 'him', 'My mother ', 'he', 'she', 'him', 'you', 'him', 'he', 'you', 'him']]
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland']], [['James Morland']], [['James Morland'], ['James Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['John Thorpe'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Mrs. Thorpe'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Mrs. Thorpe'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Henry Tilney']]]

quoteText: No, he is not here; I cannot see him anywhere.
subQuotationList: ['No,', 'he is not here; I cannot see him anywhere.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Oh, horrid! Am I never to be acquainted with him? How do you like my
gown? I think it does not look amiss; the sleeves were entirely my own
thought. Do you know, I get so immoderately sick of Bath; your brother
and I were agreeing this morning that, though it is vastly well to be
here for a few weeks, we would not live here for millions. We soon
found out that our tastes were exactly alike in preferring the country
to every other place; really, our opinions were so exactly the same, it
was quite ridiculous! There was not a single point in which we
differed; I would not have had you by for the world; you are such a sly
thing, I am sure you would have made some droll remark or other about
it.
subQuotationList:
['Oh, horrid! Am I never to be acquainted with him? How do you like my
gown? I think it does not look amiss; the sleeves were entirely my own
thought. Do you know, I get so immoderately sick of Bath; your brother
and I were agreeing this morning that, though it is vastly well to be
here for a few weeks, we would not live here for millions. We soon
found out that our tastes were exactly alike in preferring the country
to every other place; really, our opinions were so exactly the same, it
was quite ridiculous! There was not a single point in which we
differed; I would not have had you by for the world; you are such a sly
thing, I am sure you would have made some droll remark or other about
it.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Henry Tilney'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['James Morland'], ['James Morland', 'Isabella Thorpe'], ['James Morland', 'Isabella Thorpe'], ['James Morland', 'Isabella Thorpe'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText: No, indeed I should not.
subQuotationList: ['No, indeed I should not.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Oh, yes you would indeed; I know you better than you know yourself.
You would have told us that we seemed born for each other, or some
nonsense of that kind, which would have distressed me beyond
conception; my cheeks would have been as red as your roses; I would not
have had you by for the world.
subQuotationList:
['Oh, yes you would indeed; I know you better than you know yourself.
You would have told us that we seemed born for each other, or some
nonsense of that kind, which would have distressed me beyond
conception; my cheeks would have been as red as your roses; I would not
have had you by for the world.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['James Morland', 'Isabella Thorpe'], ['James Morland', 'Isabella Thorpe'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText:
Indeed you do me injustice; I would not have made so improper a remark
upon any account; and besides, I am sure it would never have entered my
head.
subQuotationList: ['Indeed you do me injustice; I would not have made so improper a remark\nupon any account; and besides, I am sure it would never have entered my\nhead.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: How well your brother dances!
subQuotationList: ['How well your brother dances!']
speaker: Catherine Morland
referringExpression: was an artless exclamation of Catherine s

quoteText: Henry! Yes, he does dance very well.
subQuotationList: ['Henry!', 'Yes, he does dance very well.']
speaker: Eleanor Tilney

quoteText:
He must have thought it very odd to hear me say I was engaged the
other evening, when he saw me sitting down. But I really had been
engaged the whole day to Mr. Thorpe. You
cannot think, how surprised
I was to see him again. I felt so sure of his being quite gone away.
subQuotationList:
['He must have thought it very odd to hear me say I was engaged the
other evening, when he saw me sitting down. But I really had been
engaged the whole day to Mr. Thorpe.', 'You
cannot think,', 'how surprised
I was to see him again. I felt so sure of his being quite gone away.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
When Henry had the pleasure of seeing you before, he was in Bath but
for a couple of days. He came only to engage lodgings for us.
subQuotationList: ['When Henry had the pleasure of seeing you before, he was in Bath but\nfor a couple of days. He came only to engage lodgings for us.']
speaker: Eleanor Tilney
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Henry Tilney'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Henry Tilney', 'Eleanor Tilney']]]

quoteText:
_That_ never occurred to me; and of course, not seeing him anywhere, I
thought he must be gone. Was not the young lady he danced with on
Monday a Miss Smith?
subQuotationList: ['_That_ never occurred to me; and of course, not seeing him anywhere, I\nthought he must be gone. Was not the young lady he danced with on\nMonday a Miss Smith?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: Yes, an acquaintance of Mrs. Hughes.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, an acquaintance of Mrs. Hughes.']
speaker: Eleanor Tilney

quoteText: I dare say she was very glad to dance. Do you think her pretty?
subQuotationList: ['I dare say she was very glad to dance. Do you think her pretty?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: Not very.
subQuotationList: ['Not very.']
speaker: Eleanor Tilney

quoteText: He never comes to the pump-room, I suppose?
subQuotationList: ['He never comes to the pump-room, I suppose?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: Yes, sometimes; but he has rid out this morning with my father.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, sometimes; but he has rid out this morning with my father.']
speaker: Eleanor Tilney

quoteText: I hope I shall have the pleasure of seeing you again soon, Shall you be at the cotillion ball tomorrow?
subQuotationList: ['I hope I shall have the pleasure of seeing you again soon,', 'Shall you be at the cotillion ball tomorrow?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: Perhaps we Yes, I think we certainly shall.
subQuotationList: ['Perhaps we Yes, I think we certainly shall.']
speaker: Eleanor Tilney
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Eleanor Tilney', 'Henry Tilney', 'Mrs. Hughes'], ['Eleanor Tilney', 'Henry Tilney', 'Mrs. Hughes']]]

quoteText: I am glad of it, for we shall all be there.
subQuotationList: ['I am glad of it, for we shall all be there.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Do not be frightened, my dear Catherine, but I
am really going to dance with your brother again. I declare positively
it is quite shocking. I tell him he ought to be ashamed of himself, but
you and John must keep us in countenance. Make haste, my dear creature,
and come to us. John is just walked off, but he will be back in a
moment.
subQuotationList:
['Do not be frightened, my dear Catherine,', 'but I
am really going to dance with your brother again. I declare positively
it is quite shocking. I tell him he ought to be ashamed of himself, but
you and John must keep us in countenance. Make haste, my dear creature,
and come to us. John is just walked off, but he will be back in a
moment.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Catherine Morland']], [['James Morland'], ['James Morland'], ['James Morland'], ['John Thorpe'], ['James Morland', 'Isabella Thorpe'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['James Morland', 'Isabella Thorpe'], ['John Thorpe'], ['John Thorpe']]]

quoteText:
Heyday, Miss Morland! What is the meaning
of this? I thought you and I were to dance together.
subQuotationList: ['Heyday, Miss Morland!', 'What is the meaning\nof this? I thought you and I were to dance together.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText: I wonder you should think so, for you never asked me.
subQuotationList: ['I wonder you should think so, for you never asked me.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
That is a good one, by Jove! I asked you as soon as I came into the
room, and I was just going to ask you again, but when I turned round,
you were gone! This is a cursed shabby trick! I only came for the sake
of dancing with _you_, and I firmly believe you were engaged to me ever
since Monday. Yes; I remember, I asked you while you were waiting in
the lobby for your cloak. And here have I been telling all my
acquaintance that I was going to dance with the prettiest girl in the
room; and when they see you standing up with somebody else, they will
quiz me famously.
subQuotationList:
['That is a good one, by Jove! I asked you as soon as I came into the
room, and I was just going to ask you again, but when I turned round,
you were gone! This is a cursed shabby trick! I only came for the sake
of dancing with _you_, and I firmly believe you were engaged to me ever
since Monday. Yes; I remember, I asked you while you were waiting in
the lobby for your cloak. And here have I been telling all my
acquaintance that I was going to dance with the prettiest girl in the
room; and when they see you standing up with somebody else, they will
quiz me famously.']
speaker: John Thorpe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText:
Oh, no; they will never think of _me_, after such a description as
that.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, no; they will never think of _me_, after such a description as\nthat.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
By heavens, if they do not, I will kick them out of the room for
blockheads. What chap have you there?
subQuotationList: ['By heavens, if they do not, I will kick them out of the room for\nblockheads. What chap have you there?']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText:
Tilney, Hum I do not know him. A good figure
of a man; well put together. Does he want a horse? Here is a friend of
mine, Sam Fletcher, has got one to sell that would suit anybody. A
famous clever animal for the road only forty guineas. I had fifty minds
to buy it myself, for it is one of my maxims always to buy a good horse
when I meet with one; but it would not answer my purpose, it would not
do for the field. I would give any money for a real good hunter. I have
three now, the best that ever were backed. I would not take eight
hundred guineas for them. Fletcher and I mean to get a house in
Leicestershire, against the next season. It is so d uncomfortable,
living at an inn.
subQuotationList:
['Tilney,', 'Hum I do not know him. A good figure
of a man; well put together. Does he want a horse? Here is a friend of
mine, Sam Fletcher, has got one to sell that would suit anybody. A
famous clever animal for the road only forty guineas. I had fifty minds
to buy it myself, for it is one of my maxims always to buy a good horse
when I meet with one; but it would not answer my purpose, it would not
do for the field. I would give any money for a real good hunter. I have
three now, the best that ever were backed. I would not take eight
hundred guineas for them. Fletcher and I mean to get a house in
Leicestershire, against the next season. It is so d uncomfortable,
living at an inn.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText:
That gentleman would have put me out of patience, had he stayed with
you half a minute longer. He has no business to withdraw the attention
of my partner from me. We have entered into a contract of mutual
agreeableness for the space of an evening, and all our agreeableness
belongs solely to each other for that time. Nobody can fasten
themselves on the notice of one, without injuring the rights of the
other. I consider a country-dance as an emblem of marriage. Fidelity
and complaisance are the principal duties of both; and those men who do
not choose to dance or marry themselves, have no business with the
partners or wives of their neighbours.
subQuotationList:
['That gentleman would have put me out of patience, had he stayed with
you half a minute longer. He has no business to withdraw the attention
of my partner from me. We have entered into a contract of mutual
agreeableness for the space of an evening, and all our agreeableness
belongs solely to each other for that time. Nobody can fasten
themselves on the notice of one, without injuring the rights of the
other. I consider a country-dance as an emblem of marriage. Fidelity
and complaisance are the principal duties of both; and those men who do
not choose to dance or marry themselves, have no business with the
partners or wives of their neighbours.']
speaker: Henry Tilney
referringExpression: Her partner now drew near and said
mentionEntitiesList: [[['John Thorpe'], ['John Thorpe'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['John Thorpe'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Henry Tilney', 'Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText: But they are such very different things!
subQuotationList: ['But they are such very different things!']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: That you think they cannot be compared together.
subQuotationList: ['That you think they cannot be compared together.']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText:
To be sure not. People that marry can never part, but must go and keep
house together. People that dance only stand opposite each other in a
long room for half an hour.
subQuotationList: ['To be sure not. People that marry can never part, but must go and keep\nhouse together. People that dance only stand opposite each other in a\nlong room for half an hour.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
And such is your definition of matrimony and dancing. Taken in that
light certainly, their resemblance is not striking; but I think I could
place them in such a view. You will allow, that in both, man has the
advantage of choice, woman only the power of refusal; that in both, it
is an engagement between man and woman, formed for the advantage of
each; and that when once entered into, they belong exclusively to each
other till the moment of its dissolution; that it is their duty, each
to endeavour to give the other no cause for wishing that he or she had
bestowed themselves elsewhere, and their best interest to keep their
own imaginations from wandering towards the perfections of their
neighbours, or fancying that they should have been better off with
anyone else. You will allow all this?
subQuotationList:
['And such is your definition of matrimony and dancing. Taken in that
light certainly, their resemblance is not striking; but I think I could
place them in such a view. You will allow, that in both, man has the
advantage of choice, woman only the power of refusal; that in both, it
is an engagement between man and woman, formed for the advantage of
each; and that when once entered into, they belong exclusively to each
other till the moment of its dissolution; that it is their duty, each
to endeavour to give the other no cause for wishing that he or she had
bestowed themselves elsewhere, and their best interest to keep their
own imaginations from wandering towards the perfections of their
neighbours, or fancying that they should have been better off with
anyone else. You will allow all this?']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText:
Yes, to be sure, as you state it, all this sounds very well; but still
they are so very different. I cannot look upon them at all in the same
light, nor think the same duties belong to them.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, to be sure, as you state it, all this sounds very well; but still\nthey are so very different. I cannot look upon them at all in the same\nlight, nor think the same duties belong to them.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
In one respect, there certainly is a difference. In marriage, the man
is supposed to provide for the support of the woman, the woman to make
the home agreeable to the man; he is to purvey, and she is to smile.
But in dancing, their duties are exactly changed; the agreeableness,
the compliance are expected from him, while she furnishes the fan and
the lavender water. _That_, I suppose, was the difference of duties
which struck you, as rendering the conditions incapable of comparison.
subQuotationList:
['In one respect, there certainly is a difference. In marriage, the man
is supposed to provide for the support of the woman, the woman to make
the home agreeable to the man; he is to purvey, and she is to smile.
But in dancing, their duties are exactly changed; the agreeableness,
the compliance are expected from him, while she furnishes the fan and
the lavender water. _That_, I suppose, was the difference of duties
which struck you, as rendering the conditions incapable of comparison.']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText: No, indeed, I never thought of that.
subQuotationList: ['No, indeed, I never thought of that.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Then I am quite at a loss. One thing, however, I must observe. This
disposition on your side is rather alarming. You totally disallow any
similarity in the obligations; and may I not thence infer that your
notions of the duties of the dancing state are not so strict as your
partner might wish? Have I not reason to fear that if the gentleman who
spoke to you just now were to return, or if any other gentleman were to
address you, there would be nothing to restrain you from conversing
with him as long as you chose?
subQuotationList:
['Then I am quite at a loss. One thing, however, I must observe. This
disposition on your side is rather alarming. You totally disallow any
similarity in the obligations; and may I not thence infer that your
notions of the duties of the dancing state are not so strict as your
partner might wish? Have I not reason to fear that if the gentleman who
spoke to you just now were to return, or if any other gentleman were to
address you, there would be nothing to restrain you from conversing
with him as long as you chose?']
speaker: Henry Tilney
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText:
Mr. Thorpe is such a very particular friend of my brother s, that if
he talks to me, I must talk to him again; but there are hardly three
young men in the room besides him that I have any acquaintance with.
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Thorpe is such a very particular friend of my brother s, that if\nhe talks to me, I must talk to him again; but there are hardly three\nyoung men in the room besides him that I have any acquaintance with.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: And is that to be my only security? Alas, alas!
subQuotationList: ['And is that to be my only security? Alas, alas!']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText:
Nay, I am sure you cannot have a better; for if I do not know anybody,
it is impossible for me to talk to them; and, besides, I do not _want_
to talk to anybody.
subQuotationList: ['Nay, I am sure you cannot have a better; for if I do not know anybody,\nit is impossible for me to talk to them; and, besides, I do not _want_\nto talk to anybody.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Now you have given me a security worth having; and I shall proceed
with courage. Do you find Bath as agreeable as when I had the honour of
making the inquiry before?
subQuotationList: ['Now you have given me a security worth having; and I shall proceed\nwith courage. Do you find Bath as agreeable as when I had the honour of\nmaking the inquiry before?']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText: Yes, quite more so, indeed.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, quite more so, indeed.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
More so! Take care, or you will forget to be tired of it at the proper
time. You ought to be tired at the end of six weeks.
subQuotationList: ['More so! Take care, or you will forget to be tired of it at the proper\ntime. You ought to be tired at the end of six weeks.']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText: I do not think I should be tired, if I were to stay here six months.
subQuotationList: ['I do not think I should be tired, if I were to stay here six months.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Bath, compared with London, has little variety, and so everybody finds
out every year.  For six weeks, I allow Bath is pleasant enough; but
beyond _that_, it is the most tiresome place in the world.  You would
be told so by people of all descriptions, who come regularly every
winter, lengthen their six weeks into ten or twelve, and go away at
last because they can afford to stay no longer.
subQuotationList:
['Bath, compared with London, has little variety, and so everybody finds
out every year.  For six weeks, I allow Bath is pleasant enough; but
beyond _that_, it is the most tiresome place in the world.  You would
be told so by people of all descriptions, who come regularly every
winter, lengthen their six weeks into ten or twelve, and go away at
last because they can afford to stay no longer.']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText:
Well, other people must judge for themselves, and those who go to
London may think nothing of Bath. But I, who live in a small retired
village in the country, can never find greater sameness in such a place
as this than in my own home; for here are a variety of amusements, a
variety of things to be seen and done all day long, which I can know
nothing of there.
subQuotationList:
['Well, other people must judge for themselves, and those who go to
London may think nothing of Bath. But I, who live in a small retired
village in the country, can never find greater sameness in such a place
as this than in my own home; for here are a variety of amusements, a
variety of things to be seen and done all day long, which I can know
nothing of there.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: You are not fond of the country.
subQuotationList: ['You are not fond of the country.']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText:
Yes, I am. I have always lived there, and always been very happy. But
certainly there is much more sameness in a country life than in a Bath
life. One day in the country is exactly like another.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I am. I have always lived there, and always been very happy. But\ncertainly there is much more sameness in a country life than in a Bath\nlife. One day in the country is exactly like another.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: But then you spend your time so much more rationally in the country.
subQuotationList: ['But then you spend your time so much more rationally in the country.']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText: Do I?
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: Do you not?
subQuotationList: ['Do you not?']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText: I do not believe there is much difference.
subQuotationList: ['I do not believe there is much difference.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: Here you are in pursuit only of amusement all day long.
subQuotationList: ['Here you are in pursuit only of amusement all day long.']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText:
And so I am at home only I do not find so much of it. I walk about
here, and so I do there; but here I see a variety of people in every
street, and there I can only go and call on Mrs. Allen.
subQuotationList: ['And so I am at home only I do not find so much of it. I walk about\nhere, and so I do there; but here I see a variety of people in every\nstreet, and there I can only go and call on Mrs. Allen.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Only go and call on Mrs. Allen! What a picture of
intellectual poverty! However, when you sink into this abyss again, you
will have more to say. You will be able to talk of Bath, and of all
that you did here.
subQuotationList:
['Only go and call on Mrs. Allen!', 'What a picture of
intellectual poverty! However, when you sink into this abyss again, you
will have more to say. You will be able to talk of Bath, and of all
that you did here.']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText:
Oh! Yes. I shall never be in want of something to talk of again to
Mrs. Allen, or anybody else. I really believe I shall always be talking
of Bath, when I am at home again I _do_ like it so very much. If I
could but have Papa and Mamma, and the rest of them here, I suppose I
should be too happy! James s coming (my eldest brother) is quite
delightful and especially as it turns out that the very family we are
just got so intimate with are his intimate friends already. Oh! Who can
ever be tired of Bath?
subQuotationList:
['Oh! Yes. I shall never be in want of something to talk of again to
Mrs. Allen, or anybody else. I really believe I shall always be talking
of Bath, when I am at home again I _do_ like it so very much. If I
could but have Papa and Mamma, and the rest of them here, I suppose I
should be too happy! James s coming (my eldest brother) is quite
delightful and especially as it turns out that the very family we are
just got so intimate with are his intimate friends already. Oh! Who can
ever be tired of Bath?']
speaker: Catherine Morland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Allen'], ['Mr. Morland'], ['Mrs. Morland'], ['James Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['James Morland']]]

quoteText:
Not those who bring such fresh feelings of every sort to it as you do.
But papas and mammas, and brothers, and intimate friends are a good
deal gone by, to most of the frequenters of Bath and the honest relish
of balls and plays, and everyday sights, is past with them.
subQuotationList:
['Not those who bring such fresh feelings of every sort to it as you do.
But papas and mammas, and brothers, and intimate friends are a good
deal gone by, to most of the frequenters of Bath and the honest relish
of balls and plays, and everyday sights, is past with them.']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText:
I
see that you guess what I have just been asked. That gentleman knows
your name, and you have a right to know his. It is General Tilney, my
father.
subQuotationList:
['I
see that you guess what I have just been asked. That gentleman knows
your name, and you have a right to know his. It is General Tilney, my
father.']
speaker: Henry Tilney
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Catherine Morland'], ['General Tilney'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['General Tilney'], ['General Tilney'], ['General Tilney']]]

quoteText: Oh!
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
How handsome a
family they are!
subQuotationList: ['How handsome a\nfamily they are!']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
I shall like
it, beyond anything in the world; and do not let us put it
off let us go tomorrow.
subQuotationList: ['I shall like\nit,', 'beyond anything in the world; and do not let us put it\noff let us go tomorrow.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: Remember twelve o clock,
subQuotationList: ['Remember twelve o clock,']
speaker: Catherine Morland
referringExpression: was her parting speech to her new friend

quoteText:
Oh! dear, I do believe it
will be wet,
subQuotationList: ['Oh! dear, I do believe it\nwill be wet,']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: I thought how it would be,
subQuotationList: ['I thought how it would be,']
speaker: Mrs. Allen

quoteText:
No walk for me today, but perhaps it may come to
nothing, or it may hold up before twelve.
subQuotationList: ['No walk for me today,', 'but perhaps it may come to\nnothing, or it may hold up before twelve.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: Perhaps it may, but then, my dear, it will be so dirty.
subQuotationList: ['Perhaps it may, but then, my dear, it will be so dirty.']
speaker: Mrs. Allen

quoteText: Oh! That will not signify; I never mind dirt.
subQuotationList: ['Oh! That will not signify; I never mind dirt.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: No, I know you never mind dirt.
subQuotationList: ['No,', 'I know you never mind dirt.']
speaker: Mrs. Allen

quoteText: It comes on faster and faster!
subQuotationList: ['It comes on faster and faster!']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: So it does indeed. If it keeps raining, the streets will be very wet.
subQuotationList: ['So it does indeed. If it keeps raining, the streets will be very wet.']
speaker: Mrs. Allen

quoteText:
There are four umbrellas up already. How I hate the sight of an
umbrella!
subQuotationList: ['There are four umbrellas up already. How I hate the sight of an\numbrella!']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
They are disagreeable things to carry. I would much rather take a
chair at any time.
subQuotationList: ['They are disagreeable things to carry. I would much rather take a\nchair at any time.']
speaker: Mrs. Allen

quoteText:
It was such a nice-looking morning! I felt so convinced it would be
dry!
subQuotationList: ['It was such a nice-looking morning! I felt so convinced it would be\ndry!']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Anybody would have thought so indeed. There will be very few people in
the pump-room, if it rains all the morning. I hope Mr. Allen will put
on his greatcoat when he goes, but I dare say he will not, for he had
rather do anything in the world than walk out in a greatcoat; I wonder
he should dislike it, it must be so comfortable.
subQuotationList:
['Anybody would have thought so indeed. There will be very few people in
the pump-room, if it rains all the morning. I hope Mr. Allen will put
on his greatcoat when he goes, but I dare say he will not, for he had
rather do anything in the world than walk out in a greatcoat; I wonder
he should dislike it, it must be so comfortable.']
speaker: Mrs. Allen
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Allen'], ['Mr. Allen'], ['Mr. Allen'], ['Mr. Allen'], ['Mr. Allen'], ['Mr. Allen']]]

quoteText:
You will not
be able to go, my dear.
subQuotationList: ['You will not\nbe able to go, my dear.']
speaker: Mrs. Allen

quoteText:
I do not quite despair yet. I shall not give it up till a quarter
after twelve. This is just the time of day for it to clear up, and I do
think it looks a little lighter. There, it is twenty minutes after
twelve, and now I _shall_ give it up entirely. Oh! That we had such
weather here as they had at Udolpho, or at least in Tuscany and the
south of France! the night that poor St. Aubin died! such beautiful
weather!
subQuotationList:
['I do not quite despair yet. I shall not give it up till a quarter
after twelve. This is just the time of day for it to clear up, and I do
think it looks a little lighter. There, it is twenty minutes after
twelve, and now I _shall_ give it up entirely. Oh! That we had such
weather here as they had at Udolpho, or at least in Tuscany and the
south of France! the night that poor St. Aubin died! such beautiful
weather!']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
always
thought it would clear up.
subQuotationList: ['always\nthought it would clear up.']
speaker: Mrs. Allen

quoteText:
Isabella, my brother, and Mr. Thorpe, I declare! They are coming for
me perhaps but I shall not go I cannot go indeed, for you know Miss
Tilney may still call.
subQuotationList: ['Isabella, my brother, and Mr. Thorpe, I declare! They are coming for\nme perhaps but I shall not go I cannot go indeed, for you know Miss\nTilney may still call.']
speaker: Catherine Morland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Isabella Thorpe'], ['James Morland'], ['John Thorpe'], ['James Morland', 'Isabella Thorpe', 'John Thorpe'], ['Mrs. Allen'], ['Eleanor Tilney']]]

quoteText:
Make haste! Make haste! Put on your hat this moment there is no
time to be lost we are going to Bristol. How d ye do, Mrs. Allen?
subQuotationList: ['Make haste! Make haste!', 'Put on your hat this moment there is no\ntime to be lost we are going to Bristol. How d ye do, Mrs. Allen?']
speaker: John Thorpe
referringExpression: he was calling out to Miss Morland

quoteText:
To Bristol! Is not that a great way off? But, however, I cannot go
with you today, because I am engaged; I expect some friends every
moment.
subQuotationList: ['To Bristol! Is not that a great way off? But, however, I cannot go\nwith you today, because I am engaged; I expect some friends every\nmoment.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
My sweetest Catherine, is not this
delightful? We shall have a most heavenly drive. You are to thank your
brother and me for the scheme; it darted into our heads at
breakfast-time, I verily believe at the same instant; and we should
have been off two hours ago if it had not been for this detestable
rain. But it does not signify, the nights are moonlight, and we shall
do delightfully. Oh! I am in such ecstasies at the thoughts of a little
country air and quiet! So much better than going to the Lower Rooms. We
shall drive directly to Clifton and dine there; and, as soon as dinner
is over, if there is time for it, go on to Kingsweston.
subQuotationList:
['My sweetest Catherine, is not this
delightful? We shall have a most heavenly drive. You are to thank your
brother and me for the scheme; it darted into our heads at
breakfast-time, I verily believe at the same instant; and we should
have been off two hours ago if it had not been for this detestable
rain. But it does not signify, the nights are moonlight, and we shall
do delightfully. Oh! I am in such ecstasies at the thoughts of a little
country air and quiet! So much better than going to the Lower Rooms. We
shall drive directly to Clifton and dine there; and, as soon as dinner
is over, if there is time for it, go on to Kingsweston.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Catherine Morland'], ['James Morland', 'Isabella Thorpe', 'John Thorpe', 'Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['James Morland'], ['James Morland', 'Isabella Thorpe'], ['James Morland', 'Isabella Thorpe', 'John Thorpe', 'Catherine Morland'], ['James Morland', 'Isabella Thorpe', 'John Thorpe', 'Catherine Morland'], ['James Morland', 'Isabella Thorpe', 'John Thorpe', 'Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText: I doubt our being able to do so much,
subQuotationList: ['I doubt our being able to do so much,']
speaker: James Morland

quoteText:
You croaking fellow! We shall be able to do ten times
more. Kingsweston! Aye, and Blaize Castle too, and anything else we can
hear of; but here is your sister says she will not go.
subQuotationList: ['You croaking fellow!', 'We shall be able to do ten times\nmore. Kingsweston! Aye, and Blaize Castle too, and anything else we can\nhear of; but here is your sister says she will not go.']
speaker: John Thorpe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['James Morland']], [['James Morland', 'Isabella Thorpe', 'John Thorpe', 'Catherine Morland'], ['James Morland', 'Isabella Thorpe', 'John Thorpe', 'Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText: Blaize Castle! What is that?
subQuotationList: ['Blaize Castle!', 'What is that?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
The finest place in England worth going fifty miles at any time to
see.
subQuotationList: ['The finest place in England worth going fifty miles at any time to\nsee.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText: What, is it really a castle, an old castle?
subQuotationList: ['What, is it really a castle, an old castle?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: The oldest in the kingdom.
subQuotationList: ['The oldest in the kingdom.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText: But is it like what one reads of?
subQuotationList: ['But is it like what one reads of?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: Exactly the very same.
subQuotationList: ['Exactly the very same.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText: But now really are there towers and long galleries?
subQuotationList: ['But now really are there towers and long galleries?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: By dozens.
subQuotationList: ['By dozens.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText: Then I should like to see it; but I cannot I cannot go.
subQuotationList: ['Then I should like to see it; but I cannot I cannot go.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: Not go! My beloved creature, what do you mean?
subQuotationList: ['Not go! My beloved creature, what do you mean?']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe

quoteText: I cannot go, because
subQuotationList: ['I cannot go, because']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
I expect Miss Tilney and her brother to call on me to take a
country walk. They promised to come at twelve, only it rained; but now,
as it is so fine, I dare say they will be here soon.
subQuotationList: ['I expect Miss Tilney and her brother to call on me to take a\ncountry walk. They promised to come at twelve, only it rained; but now,\nas it is so fine, I dare say they will be here soon.']
speaker: Catherine Morland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Eleanor Tilney'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Henry Tilney', 'Eleanor Tilney'], ['Henry Tilney', 'Eleanor Tilney']]]

quoteText:
Not they indeed, for, as we turned into Broad Street,
I saw them does he not drive a phaeton with bright chestnuts?
subQuotationList: ['Not they indeed,', 'for, as we turned into Broad Street,\nI saw them does he not drive a phaeton with bright chestnuts?']
speaker: John Thorpe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Henry Tilney', 'Eleanor Tilney']], [['James Morland', 'Isabella Thorpe', 'John Thorpe'], ['Henry Tilney', 'Eleanor Tilney'], ['Henry Tilney']]]

quoteText: I do not know indeed.
subQuotationList: ['I do not know indeed.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Yes, I know he does; I saw him. You are talking of the man you danced
with last night, are not you?
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I know he does; I saw him. You are talking of the man you danced\nwith last night, are not you?']
speaker: John Thorpe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Henry Tilney'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Well, I saw him at that moment turn up the Lansdown Road, driving a
smart-looking girl.
subQuotationList: ['Well, I saw him at that moment turn up the Lansdown Road, driving a\nsmart-looking girl.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText: Did you indeed?
subQuotationList: ['Did you indeed?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Did upon my soul; knew him again directly, and he seemed to have got
some very pretty cattle too.
subQuotationList: ['Did upon my soul; knew him again directly, and he seemed to have got\nsome very pretty cattle too.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText:
It is very odd! But I suppose they thought it would be too dirty for a
walk.
subQuotationList: ['It is very odd! But I suppose they thought it would be too dirty for a\nwalk.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
And well they might, for I never saw so much dirt in my life. Walk!
You could no more walk than you could fly! It has not been so dirty the
whole winter; it is ankle-deep everywhere.
subQuotationList: ['And well they might, for I never saw so much dirt in my life. Walk!\nYou could no more walk than you could fly! It has not been so dirty the\nwhole winter; it is ankle-deep everywhere.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText:
My dearest Catherine, you cannot form an
idea of the dirt; come, you must go; you cannot refuse going now.
subQuotationList: ['My dearest Catherine, you cannot form an\nidea of the dirt; come, you must go; you cannot refuse going now.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe

quoteText:
I should like to see the castle; but may we go all over it? May we go
up every staircase, and into every suite of rooms?
subQuotationList: ['I should like to see the castle; but may we go all over it? May we go\nup every staircase, and into every suite of rooms?']
speaker: Catherine Morland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['James Morland', 'Isabella Thorpe', 'John Thorpe', 'Catherine Morland'], ['James Morland', 'Isabella Thorpe', 'John Thorpe', 'Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText: Yes, yes, every hole and corner.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, yes, every hole and corner.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe

quoteText:
But then, if they should only be gone out for an hour till it is
dryer, and call by and by?
subQuotationList: ['But then, if they should only be gone out for an hour till it is\ndryer, and call by and by?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Make yourself easy, there is no danger of that, for I heard Tilney
hallooing to a man who was just passing by on horseback, that they were
going as far as Wick Rocks.
subQuotationList: ['Make yourself easy, there is no danger of that, for I heard Tilney\nhallooing to a man who was just passing by on horseback, that they were\ngoing as far as Wick Rocks.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText: Then I will. Shall I go, Mrs. Allen?
subQuotationList: ['Then I will. Shall I go, Mrs. Allen?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: Just as you please, my dear.
subQuotationList: ['Just as you please, my dear.']
speaker: Mrs. Allen

quoteText:
Well, my dear, suppose
you go.
subQuotationList: ['Well, my dear,', 'suppose\nyou go.']
speaker: Mrs. Allen

quoteText: Who is that girl who looked at you so hard as she went by?
subQuotationList: ['Who is that girl who looked at you so hard as she went by?']
speaker: John Thorpe
referringExpression: she was roused by this address from her companion

quoteText: Who? Where?
subQuotationList: ['Who? Where?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: On the right-hand pavement she must be almost out of sight now.
subQuotationList: ['On the right-hand pavement she must be almost out of sight now.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText:
Stop, stop, Mr. Thorpe, it is Miss
Tilney; it is indeed. How could you tell me they were gone? Stop, stop,
I will get out this moment and go to them.
subQuotationList: ['Stop, stop, Mr. Thorpe,', 'it is Miss\nTilney; it is indeed. How could you tell me they were gone? Stop, stop,\nI will get out this moment and go to them.']
speaker: Catherine Morland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['John Thorpe']], [['Eleanor Tilney'], ['John Thorpe'], ['Henry Tilney', 'Eleanor Tilney'], ['Henry Tilney', 'Eleanor Tilney']]]

quoteText:
Pray, pray stop, Mr.
Thorpe. I cannot go on. I will not go on. I must go back to Miss
Tilney.
subQuotationList: ['Pray, pray stop, Mr.\nThorpe. I cannot go on. I will not go on. I must go back to Miss\nTilney.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
How could
you deceive me so, Mr. Thorpe? How could you say that you saw them
driving up the Lansdown Road? I would not have had it happen so for the
world. They must think it so strange, so rude of me! To go by them,
too, without saying a word! You do not know how vexed I am; I shall
have no pleasure at Clifton, nor in anything else. I had rather, ten
thousand times rather, get out now, and walk back to them. How could
you say you saw them driving out in a phaeton?
subQuotationList:
['How could
you deceive me so, Mr. Thorpe? How could you say that you saw them
driving up the Lansdown Road? I would not have had it happen so for the
world. They must think it so strange, so rude of me! To go by them,
too, without saying a word! You do not know how vexed I am; I shall
have no pleasure at Clifton, nor in anything else. I had rather, ten
thousand times rather, get out now, and walk back to them. How could
you say you saw them driving out in a phaeton?']
speaker: Catherine Morland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['John Thorpe'], ['John Thorpe'], ['John Thorpe'], ['John Thorpe'], ['Henry Tilney', 'Eleanor Tilney'], ['Henry Tilney', 'Eleanor Tilney'], ['Henry Tilney', 'Eleanor Tilney'], ['John Thorpe'], ['Henry Tilney', 'Eleanor Tilney'], ['John Thorpe'], ['John Thorpe'], ['Henry Tilney', 'Eleanor Tilney']]]

quoteText:
We had better go back, Thorpe; it is
too late to go on today; your sister thinks so as well as I. We have
been exactly an hour coming from Pulteney Street, very little more than
seven miles; and, I suppose, we have at least eight more to go. It will
never do. We set out a great deal too late. We had much better put it
off till another day, and turn round.
subQuotationList:
['We had better go back, Thorpe; it is
too late to go on today; your sister thinks so as well as I. We have
been exactly an hour coming from Pulteney Street, very little more than
seven miles; and, I suppose, we have at least eight more to go. It will
never do. We set out a great deal too late. We had much better put it
off till another day, and turn round.']
speaker: James Morland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['James Morland', 'Isabella Thorpe', 'John Thorpe', 'Catherine Morland'], ['John Thorpe'], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['James Morland', 'Isabella Thorpe', 'John Thorpe', 'Catherine Morland'], ['James Morland', 'Isabella Thorpe', 'John Thorpe', 'Catherine Morland'], ['James Morland', 'Isabella Thorpe', 'John Thorpe', 'Catherine Morland'], ['James Morland', 'Isabella Thorpe', 'John Thorpe', 'Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText: It is all one to me,
subQuotationList: ['It is all one to me,']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText:
If your brother had not got such a d beast to drive, we might have done it very well. My horse would have
trotted to Clifton within the hour, if left to himself, and I have
almost broke my arm with pulling him in to that cursed broken-winded
jade s pace. Morland is a fool for not keeping a horse and gig of his
own.
subQuotationList:
['If your brother had not got such a d beast to drive,', 'we might have done it very well. My horse would have
trotted to Clifton within the hour, if left to himself, and I have
almost broke my arm with pulling him in to that cursed broken-winded
jade s pace. Morland is a fool for not keeping a horse and gig of his
own.']
speaker: John Thorpe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['James Morland']], [['James Morland', 'Isabella Thorpe', 'John Thorpe', 'Catherine Morland'], ['James Morland']]]

quoteText:
No, he is not, for I am sure he could not
afford it.
subQuotationList: ['No, he is not,', 'for I am sure he could not\nafford it.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: And why cannot he afford it?
subQuotationList: ['And why cannot he afford it?']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText: Because he has not money enough.
subQuotationList: ['Because he has not money enough.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: And whose fault is that?
subQuotationList: ['And whose fault is that?']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText: Nobody s, that I know of.
subQuotationList: ['Nobody s, that I know of.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
I am glad your
brother had so much sense; I am glad you are come back. It was a
strange, wild scheme.
subQuotationList: ['I am glad your\nbrother had so much sense; I am glad you are come back. It was a\nstrange, wild scheme.']
speaker: Mr. Allen
referringExpression: Mr Allen who on hearing the reason of their speedy return said

quoteText:
How I pity the poor creatures that are going
there! How glad I am that I am not amongst them! I wonder whether it
will be a full ball or not! They have not begun dancing yet. I would
not be there for all the world. It is so delightful to have an evening
now and then to oneself. I dare say it will not be a very good ball. I
know the Mitchells will not be there. I am sure I pity everybody that
is. But I dare say, Mr. Morland, you long to be at it, do not you? I am
sure you do. Well, pray do not let anybody here be a restraint on you.
I dare say we could do very well without you; but you men think
yourselves of such consequence.
subQuotationList:
['How I pity the poor creatures that are going
there! How glad I am that I am not amongst them! I wonder whether it
will be a full ball or not! They have not begun dancing yet. I would
not be there for all the world. It is so delightful to have an evening
now and then to oneself. I dare say it will not be a very good ball. I
know the Mitchells will not be there. I am sure I pity everybody that
is. But I dare say, Mr. Morland, you long to be at it, do not you? I am
sure you do. Well, pray do not let anybody here be a restraint on you.
I dare say we could do very well without you; but you men think
yourselves of such consequence.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['James Morland'], ['James Morland'], ['James Morland'], ['James Morland'], ['James Morland'], ['Isabella Thorpe', 'John Thorpe', 'Catherine Morland'], ['James Morland'], ['James Morland']]]

quoteText:
Do not be so dull, my dearest creature, You
will quite break my heart. It was amazingly shocking, to be sure; but
the Tilneys were entirely to blame. Why were not they more punctual? It
was dirty, indeed, but what did that signify? I am sure John and I
should not have minded it. I never mind going through anything, where a
friend is concerned; that is my disposition, and John is just the same;
he has amazing strong feelings. Good heavens! What a delightful hand
you have got! Kings, I vow! I never was so happy in my life! I would
fifty times rather you should have them than myself.
subQuotationList:
['Do not be so dull, my dearest creature,', 'You
will quite break my heart. It was amazingly shocking, to be sure; but
the Tilneys were entirely to blame. Why were not they more punctual? It
was dirty, indeed, but what did that signify? I am sure John and I
should not have minded it. I never mind going through anything, where a
friend is concerned; that is my disposition, and John is just the same;
he has amazing strong feelings. Good heavens! What a delightful hand
you have got! Kings, I vow! I never was so happy in my life! I would
fifty times rather you should have them than myself.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Catherine Morland']], [['Catherine Morland'], ['Henry Tilney', 'Eleanor Tilney'], ['Henry Tilney', 'Eleanor Tilney'], ['John Thorpe'], ['John Thorpe'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText:
Mrs. Allen, will there be any harm
in my calling on Miss Tilney today? I shall not be easy till I have
explained everything.
subQuotationList: ['Mrs. Allen,', 'will there be any harm\nin my calling on Miss Tilney today? I shall not be easy till I have\nexplained everything.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Go, by all means, my dear; only put on a white gown; Miss Tilney
always wears white.
subQuotationList: ['Go, by all means, my dear; only put on a white gown; Miss Tilney\nalways wears white.']
speaker: Mrs. Allen

quoteText: quite horrid.
subQuotationList: ['quite horrid.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe

quoteText:
Oh! Mr. Tilney, I have been
quite wild to speak to you, and make my apologies. You must have
thought me so rude; but indeed it was not my own fault, was it, Mrs.
Allen? Did not they tell me that Mr. Tilney and his sister were gone
out in a phaeton together? And then what could I do? But I had ten
thousand times rather have been with you; now had not I, Mrs. Allen?
subQuotationList:
['Oh! Mr. Tilney, I have been
quite wild to speak to you, and make my apologies. You must have
thought me so rude; but indeed it was not my own fault, was it, Mrs.
Allen? Did not they tell me that Mr. Tilney and his sister were gone
out in a phaeton together? And then what could I do? But I had ten
thousand times rather have been with you; now had not I, Mrs. Allen?']
speaker: Catherine Morland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Henry Tilney'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Mrs. Allen'], ['James Morland', 'Isabella Thorpe', 'John Thorpe'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Eleanor Tilney'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Mrs. Allen']]]

quoteText: My dear, you tumble my gown,
subQuotationList: ['My dear, you tumble my gown,']
speaker: Mrs. Allen

quoteText:
We
were much obliged to you at any rate for wishing us a pleasant walk
after our passing you in Argyle Street: you were so kind as to look
back on purpose.
subQuotationList:
['We
were much obliged to you at any rate for wishing us a pleasant walk
after our passing you in Argyle Street: you were so kind as to look
back on purpose.']
speaker: Henry Tilney
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Eleanor Tilney', 'Henry Tilney'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Henry Tilney', 'Eleanor Tilney'], ['Eleanor Tilney', 'Henry Tilney'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText:
But indeed I did not wish you a pleasant walk; I never thought of such
a thing; but I begged Mr. Thorpe so earnestly to stop; I called out to
him as soon as ever I saw you; now, Mrs. Allen, did not Oh! You were
not there; but indeed I did; and, if Mr. Thorpe would only have
stopped, I would have jumped out and run after you.
subQuotationList:
['But indeed I did not wish you a pleasant walk; I never thought of such
a thing; but I begged Mr. Thorpe so earnestly to stop; I called out to
him as soon as ever I saw you; now, Mrs. Allen, did not Oh! You were
not there; but indeed I did; and, if Mr. Thorpe would only have
stopped, I would have jumped out and run after you.']
speaker: Catherine Morland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Henry Tilney'], ['John Thorpe'], ['John Thorpe'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Mrs. Allen'], ['John Thorpe'], ['Henry Tilney']]]

quoteText:
Oh! Do not say Miss Tilney was
not angry, because I know she was; for she would not
see me this morning when I called; I saw her walk out of the house the
next minute after my leaving it; I was hurt, but I was not affronted.
Perhaps you did not know I had been there.
subQuotationList:
['Oh! Do not say Miss Tilney was
not angry,', 'because I know she was; for she would not
see me this morning when I called; I saw her walk out of the house the
next minute after my leaving it; I was hurt, but I was not affronted.
Perhaps you did not know I had been there.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
I was not within at the time; but I heard of it from Eleanor, and she
has been wishing ever since to see you, to explain the reason of such
incivility; but perhaps I can do it as well. It was nothing more than
that my father they were just preparing to walk out, and he being
hurried for time, and not caring to have it put off made a point of her
being denied. That was all, I do assure you. She was very much vexed,
and meant to make her apology as soon as possible.
subQuotationList:
['I was not within at the time; but I heard of it from Eleanor, and she
has been wishing ever since to see you, to explain the reason of such
incivility; but perhaps I can do it as well. It was nothing more than
that my father they were just preparing to walk out, and he being
hurried for time, and not caring to have it put off made a point of her
being denied. That was all, I do assure you. She was very much vexed,
and meant to make her apology as soon as possible.']
speaker: Henry Tilney
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Eleanor Tilney'], ['Eleanor Tilney'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['General Tilney'], ['Eleanor Tilney', 'General Tilney'], ['General Tilney'], ['Eleanor Tilney'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Eleanor Tilney'], ['Eleanor Tilney']]]

quoteText:
But, Mr. Tilney, why were _you_ less generous than your
sister? If she felt such confidence in my good intentions, and could
suppose it to be only a mistake, why should _you_ be so ready to take
offence?
subQuotationList:
['But, Mr. Tilney, why were _you_ less generous than your
sister? If she felt such confidence in my good intentions, and could
suppose it to be only a mistake, why should _you_ be so ready to take
offence?']
speaker: Catherine Morland
referringExpression: Catherine s mind was greatly eased by this information yet a something of solicitude remained from which sprang

quoteText: Me! I take offence!
subQuotationList: ['Me! I take offence!']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText:
Nay, I am sure by your look, when you came into the box, you were
angry.
subQuotationList: ['Nay, I am sure by your look, when you came into the box, you were\nangry.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: I angry! I could have no right.
subQuotationList: ['I angry! I could have no right.']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText: Well, nobody would have thought you had no right who saw your face.
subQuotationList: ['Well, nobody would have thought you had no right who saw your face.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: How came Mr. Thorpe to know your father?
subQuotationList: ['How came Mr. Thorpe to know your father?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
He is a fine old fellow, upon my soul! Stout,
active looks as young as his son. I have a great regard for him, I
assure you: a gentleman-like, good sort of fellow as ever lived.
subQuotationList: ['He is a fine old fellow, upon my soul! Stout,\nactive looks as young as his son. I have a great regard for him, I\nassure you: a gentleman-like, good sort of fellow as ever lived.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText: But how came you to know him?
subQuotationList: ['But how came you to know him?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Know him! There are few people much about town that I do not know. I
have met him forever at the Bedford; and I knew his face again today
the moment he came into the billiard-room. One of the best players we
have, by the by; and we had a little touch together, though I was
almost afraid of him at first: the odds were five to four against me;
and, if I had not made one of the cleanest strokes that perhaps ever
was made in this world I took his ball exactly but I could not make you
understand it without a table; however, I _did_ beat him. A very fine
fellow; as rich as a Jew. I should like to dine with him; I dare say he
gives famous dinners. But what do you think we have been talking of?
You. Yes, by heavens! And the general thinks you the finest girl in
Bath.
subQuotationList:
['Know him! There are few people much about town that I do not know. I
have met him forever at the Bedford; and I knew his face again today
the moment he came into the billiard-room. One of the best players we
have, by the by; and we had a little touch together, though I was
almost afraid of him at first: the odds were five to four against me;
and, if I had not made one of the cleanest strokes that perhaps ever
was made in this world I took his ball exactly but I could not make you
understand it without a table; however, I _did_ beat him. A very fine
fellow; as rich as a Jew. I should like to dine with him; I dare say he
gives famous dinners. But what do you think we have been talking of?
You. Yes, by heavens! And the general thinks you the finest girl in
Bath.']
speaker: John Thorpe
mentionEntitiesList: [[['General Tilney'], ['General Tilney'], ['General Tilney'], ['General Tilney'], ['John Thorpe', 'General Tilney'], ['General Tilney'], ['General Tilney'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['General Tilney'], ['General Tilney'], ['General Tilney'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['John Thorpe', 'General Tilney'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['General Tilney'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText: Oh! Nonsense! How can you say so?
subQuotationList: ['Oh! Nonsense! How can you say so?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: And what do you think I said?
subQuotationList: ['And what do you think I said?']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText:
well done, general,
said I; I am quite of your mind.
subQuotationList: ['well done, general,\nsaid I; I am quite of your mind.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText:
Do not urge me, Isabella. I am engaged to
Miss Tilney. I cannot go.
subQuotationList: ['Do not urge me, Isabella. I am engaged to\nMiss Tilney. I cannot go.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
It would be so easy to tell Miss Tilney that you had
just been reminded of a prior engagement, and must only beg to put off
the walk till Tuesday.
subQuotationList: ['It would be so easy to tell Miss Tilney that you had\njust been reminded of a prior engagement, and must only beg to put off\nthe walk till Tuesday.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe

quoteText:
No, it would not be easy. I could not do it. There has been no prior
engagement.
subQuotationList: ['No, it would not be easy. I could not do it. There has been no prior\nengagement.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
I cannot help being
jealous, Catherine, when I see myself slighted for strangers, I, who
love you so excessively! When once my affections are placed, it is not
in the power of anything to change them. But I believe my feelings are
stronger than anybody s; I am sure they are too strong for my own
peace; and to see myself supplanted in your friendship by strangers
does cut me to the quick, I own. These Tilneys seem to swallow up
everything else.
subQuotationList:
['I cannot help being
jealous, Catherine, when I see myself slighted for strangers, I, who
love you so excessively! When once my affections are placed, it is not
in the power of anything to change them. But I believe my feelings are
stronger than anybody s; I am sure they are too strong for my own
peace; and to see myself supplanted in your friendship by strangers
does cut me to the quick, I own. These Tilneys seem to swallow up
everything else.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe

quoteText:
Nay, Catherine. I think you cannot stand out
any longer now. The sacrifice is not much; and to oblige such a
friend I shall think you quite unkind, if you still refuse.
subQuotationList: ['Nay, Catherine. I think you cannot stand out\nany longer now. The sacrifice is not much; and to oblige such a\nfriend I shall think you quite unkind, if you still refuse.']
speaker: James Morland
referringExpression: Morland miserable at such a sight could not help saying

quoteText: No, no, no!
subQuotationList: ['No, no, no!']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText:
Very well, then there is an end of the party. If
Catherine does not go, I cannot. I cannot be the only woman. I would
not, upon any account in the world, do so improper a thing.
subQuotationList: ['Very well, then there is an end of the party. If\nCatherine does not go, I cannot. I cannot be the only woman. I would\nnot, upon any account in the world, do so improper a thing.']
speaker: Isabella Thorpe
referringExpression: Isabella who in a voice of cold resentment said

quoteText: Catherine, you must go,
subQuotationList: ['Catherine, you must go,']
speaker: James Morland

quoteText:
But why cannot Mr. Thorpe drive one of his other sisters? I dare say
either of them would like to go.
subQuotationList: ['But why cannot Mr. Thorpe drive one of his other sisters? I dare say\neither of them would like to go.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Thank ye, but I did not come to Bath to drive my
sisters about, and look like a fool. No, if you do not go, d   me if I
do. I only go for the sake of driving you.
subQuotationList: ['Thank ye,', 'but I did not come to Bath to drive my\nsisters about, and look like a fool. No, if you do not go, d   me if I\ndo. I only go for the sake of driving you.']
speaker: John Thorpe

quoteText: That is a compliment which gives me no pleasure.
subQuotationList: ['That is a compliment which gives me no pleasure.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
I did not think you had been so obstinate, Catherine, you were not used to be so hard to persuade; you once were the
kindest, best-tempered of my sisters.
subQuotationList: ['I did not think you had been so obstinate, Catherine,', 'you were not used to be so hard to persuade; you once were the\nkindest, best-tempered of my sisters.']
speaker: James Morland

quoteText:
I hope I am not less so now, but indeed
