speaker: Henry Tilney
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Catherine Morland'], ['General Tilney'], ['General Tilney'], ['General Tilney'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['General Tilney'], ['General Tilney'], ['General Tilney']]]

quoteText:
I am very glad of it, it would have been very
shocking!
subQuotationList: ['I am very glad of it,', 'it would have been very\nshocking!']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
If I understand you rightly, you had formed a surmise of such horror
as I have hardly words to Dear Miss Morland, consider the dreadful
nature of the suspicions you have entertained. What have you been
judging from? Remember the country and the age in which we live.
Remember that we are English, that we are Christians. Consult your own
understanding, your own sense of the probable, your own observation of
what is passing around you. Does our education prepare us for such
atrocities? Do our laws connive at them? Could they be perpetrated
without being known, in a country like this, where social and literary
intercourse is on such a footing, where every man is surrounded by a
neighbourhood of voluntary spies, and where roads and newspapers lay
everything open? Dearest Miss Morland, what ideas have you been
admitting?
subQuotationList:
['If I understand you rightly, you had formed a surmise of such horror
as I have hardly words to Dear Miss Morland, consider the dreadful
nature of the suspicions you have entertained. What have you been
judging from? Remember the country and the age in which we live.

neighbourhood of voluntary spies, and where roads and newspapers lay

admitting?']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText: Tis only from James, however,
subQuotationList: ['Tis only from James, however,']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
No bad news from Fullerton, I
hope? Mr. and Mrs. Morland your brothers and sisters I hope they are
none of them ill?
subQuotationList: ['No bad news from Fullerton, I\nhope? Mr. and Mrs. Morland your brothers and sisters I hope they are\nnone of them ill?']
speaker: Eleanor Tilney
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Morland', 'Mr. Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Mr. Morland', 'Mrs. Morland', 'James Morland'], ['Mr. Morland', 'Mrs. Morland', 'James Morland']]]

quoteText: No, I thank you
subQuotationList: ['No, I thank you']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
they are all very well. My
letter was from my brother at Oxford.
subQuotationList: ['they are all very well. My\nletter was from my brother at Oxford.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
I do not think I shall ever wish for a letter
again!
subQuotationList: ['I do not think I shall ever wish for a letter\nagain!']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
I am sorry, if I
had suspected the letter of containing anything unwelcome, I should
have given it with very different feelings.
subQuotationList: ['I am sorry,', 'if I\nhad suspected the letter of containing anything unwelcome, I should\nhave given it with very different feelings.']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText:
It contained something worse than anybody could suppose! Poor James is
so unhappy! You will soon know why.
subQuotationList: ['It contained something worse than anybody could suppose! Poor James is\nso unhappy! You will soon know why.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: To have so kind-hearted, so affectionate a sister, must be a comfort to him under any distress.
subQuotationList: ['To have so kind-hearted, so affectionate a sister,', 'must be a comfort to him under any distress.']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText:
I have one favour to beg, that, if your brother should be coming here, you will
give me notice of it, that I may go away.
subQuotationList: ['I have one favour to beg,', 'that, if your brother should be coming here, you will\ngive me notice of it, that I may go away.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Yes; I am sure I should be very sorry to leave you so soon, but
something has happened that would make it very dreadful for me to be in
the same house with Captain Tilney.
subQuotationList: ['Yes; I am sure I should be very sorry to leave you so soon, but\nsomething has happened that would make it very dreadful for me to be in\nthe same house with Captain Tilney.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
How quick you are! you have guessed it, I declare!
And yet, when we talked about it in Bath, you little thought of its
ending so. Isabella no wonder _now_ I have not heard from her Isabella
has deserted my brother, and is to marry yours! Could you have believed
there had been such inconstancy and fickleness, and everything that is
bad in the world?
subQuotationList:
['How quick you are!', 'you have guessed it, I declare!
And yet, when we talked about it in Bath, you little thought of its
ending so. Isabella no wonder _now_ I have not heard from her Isabella
has deserted my brother, and is to marry yours! Could you have believed
there had been such inconstancy and fickleness, and everything that is

speaker: Catherine Morland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Henry Tilney']], [['Henry Tilney'], ['Henry Tilney', 'Catherine Morland'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['James Morland'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Henry Tilney']]]

quoteText:
I hope, so far as concerns my brother, you are misinformed. I hope he
has not had any material share in bringing on Mr. Morland s
disappointment. His marrying Miss Thorpe is not probable. I think you
must be deceived so far. I am very sorry for Mr. Morland sorry that
anyone you love should be unhappy; but my surprise would be greater at
Frederick s marrying her than at any other part of the story.

It is very true, however; you shall read James s letter yourself.
Stay There is one part
subQuotationList: ['It is very true, however; you shall read James s letter yourself.\nStay There is one part']

quoteText:
Will you take the trouble of reading to us the passages which concern
my brother?
subQuotationList: ['Will you take the trouble of reading to us the passages which concern\nmy brother?']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText: No, read it yourself, I do not know what I was thinking of James only means to give me good advice.
subQuotationList: ['No, read it yourself,', 'I do not know what I was thinking of', 'James only means to give me good advice.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Well, if it is to be so, I can only say
that I am sorry for it. Frederick will not be the first man who has
chosen a wife with less sense than his family expected. I do not envy
his situation, either as a lover or a son.
subQuotationList:
['Well, if it is to be so, I can only say

speaker: Henry Tilney
referringExpression: He gladly received the letter and having read it through with close attention returned it saying

quoteText: Her mother is a very good sort of woman,
subQuotationList: ['Her mother is a very good sort of woman,']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: What was her father?
subQuotationList: ['What was her father?']
speaker: Eleanor Tilney

quoteText: A lawyer, I believe. They live at Putney.
subQuotationList: ['A lawyer, I believe. They live at Putney.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: Are they a wealthy family?
subQuotationList: ['Are they a wealthy family?']
speaker: Eleanor Tilney

quoteText:
No, not very. I do not believe Isabella has any fortune at all: but
that will not signify in your family. Your father is so very liberal!
He told me the other day that he only valued money as it allowed him to
promote the happiness of his children.
subQuotationList:
['No, not very. I do not believe Isabella has any fortune at all: but
that will not signify in your family. Your father is so very liberal!
He told me the other day that he only valued money as it allowed him to
promote the happiness of his children.']
speaker: Catherine Morland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['General Tilney'], ['General Tilney'], ['General Tilney'], ['Henry Tilney', 'Eleanor Tilney', 'Frederick Tilney ']]]

quoteText:
But, would it be
to promote his happiness, to enable him to marry such a girl? She must
be an unprincipled one, or she could not have used your brother so. And
how strange an infatuation on Frederick s side! A girl who, before his
eyes, is violating an engagement voluntarily entered into with another
man! Is not it inconceivable, Henry? Frederick too, who always wore his
heart so proudly! Who found no woman good enough to be loved!
subQuotationList:
['But,', 'would it be
to promote his happiness, to enable him to marry such a girl? She must
be an unprincipled one, or she could not have used your brother so. And
how strange an infatuation on Frederick s side! A girl who, before his
eyes, is violating an engagement voluntarily entered into with another
man! Is not it inconceivable, Henry? Frederick too, who always wore his
heart so proudly! Who found no woman good enough to be loved!']
speaker: Eleanor Tilney
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Frederick Tilney '], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Frederick Tilney '], ['Frederick Tilney '], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Frederick Tilney '], ['Frederick Tilney ']]]

quoteText:
That is the most unpromising circumstance, the strongest presumption
against him. When I think of his past declarations, I give him up.
Moreover, I have too good an opinion of Miss Thorpe s prudence to
suppose that she would part with one gentleman before the other was
secured. It is all over with Frederick indeed! He is a deceased
man defunct in understanding. Prepare for your sister-in-law, Eleanor,
and such a sister-in-law as you must delight in! Open, candid, artless,
guileless, with affections strong but simple, forming no pretensions,
and knowing no disguise.
subQuotationList:
['That is the most unpromising circumstance, the strongest presumption
against him. When I think of his past declarations, I give him up.
Moreover, I have too good an opinion of Miss Thorpe s prudence to
suppose that she would part with one gentleman before the other was
secured. It is all over with Frederick indeed! He is a deceased
man defunct in understanding. Prepare for your sister-in-law, Eleanor,
and such a sister-in-law as you must delight in! Open, candid, artless,

speaker: Henry Tilney
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Frederick Tilney '], ['Frederick Tilney '], ['Frederick Tilney '], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Frederick Tilney '], ['Frederick Tilney '], ['Eleanor Tilney'], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Eleanor Tilney'], ['Eleanor Tilney']]]

quoteText: Such a sister-in-law, Henry, I should delight in,
subQuotationList: ['Such a sister-in-law, Henry, I should delight in,']
speaker: Eleanor Tilney

quoteText:
But perhaps, though she has behaved so ill by
our family, she may behave better by yours. Now she has really got the
man she likes, she may be constant.
subQuotationList: ['But perhaps,', 'though she has behaved so ill by\nour family, she may behave better by yours. Now she has really got the\nman she likes, she may be constant.']
speaker: Catherine Morland
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Catherine Morland', 'James Morland', 'Mr. Morland', 'Mrs. Morland'], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Henry Tilney', 'Eleanor Tilney'], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Isabella Thorpe']]]

quoteText:
Indeed I am afraid she will, I am afraid she will be
very constant, unless a baronet should come in her way; that is
Frederick s only chance. I will get the Bath paper, and look over the
arrivals.
subQuotationList:
['Indeed I am afraid she will,', 'I am afraid she will be
very constant, unless a baronet should come in her way; that is
Frederick s only chance. I will get the Bath paper, and look over the
arrivals.']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText:
You think it is all for ambition, then? And, upon my word, there are
some things that seem very like it. I cannot forget that, when she
first knew what my father would do for them, she seemed quite
disappointed that it was not more. I never was so deceived in anyone s
character in my life before.
subQuotationList:
['You think it is all for ambition, then? And, upon my word, there are
some things that seem very like it. I cannot forget that, when she
first knew what my father would do for them, she seemed quite
disappointed that it was not more. I never was so deceived in anyone s
character in my life before.']
speaker: Catherine Morland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Henry Tilney'], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Mr. Morland'], ['James Morland', 'Isabella Thorpe'], ['Isabella Thorpe']]]

quoteText: Among all the great variety that you have known and studied.
subQuotationList: ['Among all the great variety that you have known and studied.']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText:
My own disappointment and loss in her is very great; but, as for poor
James, I suppose he will hardly ever recover it.
subQuotationList: ['My own disappointment and loss in her is very great; but, as for poor\nJames, I suppose he will hardly ever recover it.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Your brother is certainly very much to be pitied at present; but we
must not, in our concern for his sufferings, undervalue yours. You
feel, I suppose, that in losing Isabella, you lose half yourself: you
feel a void in your heart which nothing else can occupy. Society is
becoming irksome; and as for the amusements in which you were wont to
share at Bath, the very idea of them without her is abhorrent. You
would not, for instance, now go to a ball for the world. You feel that
you have no longer any friend to whom you can speak with unreserve, on
whose regard you can place dependence, or whose counsel, in any
difficulty, you could rely on. You feel all this?
subQuotationList:
['Your brother is certainly very much to be pitied at present; but we
must not, in our concern for his sufferings, undervalue yours. You
feel, I suppose, that in losing Isabella, you lose half yourself: you
feel a void in your heart which nothing else can occupy. Society is
becoming irksome; and as for the amusements in which you were wont to
share at Bath, the very idea of them without her is abhorrent. You
would not, for instance, now go to a ball for the world. You feel that
you have no longer any friend to whom you can speak with unreserve, on
whose regard you can place dependence, or whose counsel, in any
difficulty, you could rely on. You feel all this?']
speaker: Henry Tilney
mentionEntitiesList: [[['James Morland'], ['Henry Tilney', 'Catherine Morland'], ['Isabella Thorpe', 'Henry Tilney', 'Catherine Morland'], ['James Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText:
No, I do not ought
I? To say the truth, though I am hurt and grieved, that I cannot still
love her, that I am never to hear from her, perhaps never to see her
again, I do not feel so very, very much afflicted as one would have
thought.
subQuotationList:
['No,', 'I do not ought
I? To say the truth, though I am hurt and grieved, that I cannot still
love her, that I am never to hear from her, perhaps never to see her
again, I do not feel so very, very much afflicted as one would have
thought.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
You feel, as you always do, what is most to the credit of human
nature. Such feelings ought to be investigated, that they may know
themselves.
subQuotationList: ['You feel, as you always do, what is most to the credit of human\nnature. Such feelings ought to be investigated, that they may know\nthemselves.']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText:
No, my father s hands need not
be strengthened, and Frederick s confession of folly need not be
forestalled. He must tell his own story.
subQuotationList: ['No,', 'my father s hands need not\nbe strengthened, and Frederick s confession of folly need not be\nforestalled. He must tell his own story.']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText: But he will tell only half of it.
subQuotationList: ['But he will tell only half of it.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: A quarter would be enough.
subQuotationList: ['A quarter would be enough.']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText:
And when do you think, sir, I may look forward to this
pleasure? I must be at Woodston on Monday to attend the parish meeting,
and shall probably be obliged to stay two or three days.
subQuotationList: ['And when do you think, sir, I may look forward to this\npleasure? I must be at Woodston on Monday to attend the parish meeting,\nand shall probably be obliged to stay two or three days.']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText:
Well, well, we will take our chance some one of those days. There is
no need to fix. You are not to put yourself at all out of your way.
Whatever you may happen to have in the house will be enough. I think I
can answer for the young ladies making allowance for a bachelor s
table. Let me see; Monday will be a busy day with you, we will not come
on Monday; and Tuesday will be a busy one with me. I expect my surveyor
from Brockham with his report in the morning; and afterwards I cannot
in decency fail attending the club. I really could not face my
acquaintance if I stayed away now; for, as I am known to be in the
country, it would be taken exceedingly amiss; and it is a rule with me,
Miss Morland, never to give offence to any of my neighbours, if a small
sacrifice of time and attention can prevent it. They are a set of very
worthy men. They have half a buck from Northanger twice a year; and I
dine with them whenever I can. Tuesday, therefore, we may say is out of
the question. But on Wednesday, I think, Henry, you may expect us; and
we shall be with you early, that we may have time to look about us. Two
hours and three quarters will carry us to Woodston, I suppose; we shall
be in the carriage by ten; so, about a quarter before one on Wednesday,
you may look for us.
subQuotationList:
['Well, well, we will take our chance some one of those days. There is
no need to fix. You are not to put yourself at all out of your way.
Whatever you may happen to have in the house will be enough. I think I
can answer for the young ladies making allowance for a bachelor s
table. Let me see; Monday will be a busy day with you, we will not come
on Monday; and Tuesday will be a busy one with me. I expect my surveyor
from Brockham with his report in the morning; and afterwards I cannot
in decency fail attending the club. I really could not face my
acquaintance if I stayed away now; for, as I am known to be in the

sacrifice of time and attention can prevent it. They are a set of very
worthy men. They have half a buck from Northanger twice a year; and I
dine with them whenever I can. Tuesday, therefore, we may say is out of
the question. But on Wednesday, I think, Henry, you may expect us; and
we shall be with you early, that we may have time to look about us. Two
hours and three quarters will carry us to Woodston, I suppose; we shall
be in the carriage by ten; so, about a quarter before one on Wednesday,
you may look for us.']
speaker: General Tilney
mentionEntitiesList: [[['General Tilney'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Catherine Morland', 'Eleanor Tilney'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['General Tilney'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['General Tilney', 'Eleanor Tilney', 'Catherine Morland'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['General Tilney', 'Eleanor Tilney', 'Catherine Morland'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['General Tilney', 'Eleanor Tilney', 'Catherine Morland'], ['General Tilney', 'Eleanor Tilney', 'Catherine Morland'], ['General Tilney', 'Eleanor Tilney', 'Catherine Morland'], ['General Tilney', 'Eleanor Tilney', 'Catherine Morland'], ['General Tilney', 'Eleanor Tilney', 'Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText:
I am come, young ladies, in a very
moralizing strain, to observe that our pleasures in this world are
always to be paid for, and that we often purchase them at a great
disadvantage, giving ready-monied actual happiness for a draft on the
future, that may not be honoured. Witness myself, at this present hour.
Because I am to hope for the satisfaction of seeing you at Woodston on
Wednesday, which bad weather, or twenty other causes, may prevent, I
must go away directly, two days before I intended it.
subQuotationList:
['I am come, young ladies, in a very
moralizing strain, to observe that our pleasures in this world are
always to be paid for, and that we often purchase them at a great
disadvantage, giving ready-monied actual happiness for a draft on the
future, that may not be honoured. Witness myself, at this present hour.
Because I am to hope for the satisfaction of seeing you at Woodston on
Wednesday, which bad weather, or twenty other causes, may prevent, I
must go away directly, two days before I intended it.']
speaker: Henry Tilney
referringExpression: Henry about an hour afterwards came booted and greatcoated into the room where she and Eleanor were sitting and said

quoteText: Go away! And why?
subQuotationList: ['Go away!', 'And why?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Why! How can you ask the question? Because no time is to be lost in
frightening my old housekeeper out of her wits, because I must go and
prepare a dinner for you, to be sure.
subQuotationList: ['Why! How can you ask the question? Because no time is to be lost in\nfrightening my old housekeeper out of her wits, because I must go and\nprepare a dinner for you, to be sure.']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText: Oh! Not seriously!
subQuotationList: ['Oh! Not seriously!']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: Aye, and sadly too for I had much rather stay.
subQuotationList: ['Aye, and sadly too for I had much rather stay.']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText:
But how can you think of such a thing, after what the general said?
When he so particularly desired you not to give yourself any trouble,
because _anything_ would do.
subQuotationList: ['But how can you think of such a thing, after what the general said?\nWhen he so particularly desired you not to give yourself any trouble,\nbecause _anything_ would do.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
I am sure it is quite unnecessary upon your
sister s account and mine. You must know it to be so; and the general
made such a point of your providing nothing extraordinary: besides, if
he had not said half so much as he did, he has always such an excellent
dinner at home, that sitting down to a middling one for one day could
not signify.
subQuotationList:
['I am sure it is quite unnecessary upon your
sister s account and mine. You must know it to be so; and the general
made such a point of your providing nothing extraordinary: besides, if
he had not said half so much as he did, he has always such an excellent
dinner at home, that sitting down to a middling one for one day could
not signify.']
speaker: Catherine Morland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Eleanor Tilney'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['General Tilney'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['General Tilney'], ['General Tilney'], ['General Tilney']]]

quoteText:
I wish I could reason like you, for his sake and my own. Good-bye. As
tomorrow is Sunday, Eleanor, I shall not return.
subQuotationList: ['I wish I could reason like you, for his sake and my own. Good-bye. As\ntomorrow is Sunday, Eleanor, I shall not return.']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText:
We are not calling it a good house, We are not comparing it
with Fullerton and Northanger we are considering it as a mere
parsonage, small and confined, we allow, but decent, perhaps, and
habitable; and altogether not inferior to the generality; or, in other
words, I believe there are few country parsonages in England half so
good. It may admit of improvement, however. Far be it from me to say
otherwise; and anything in reason a bow thrown out, perhaps though,
between ourselves, if there is one thing more than another my aversion,
it is a patched-on bow.
subQuotationList:
['We are not calling it a good house,', 'We are not comparing it
with Fullerton and Northanger we are considering it as a mere
parsonage, small and confined, we allow, but decent, perhaps, and
habitable; and altogether not inferior to the generality; or, in other
words, I believe there are few country parsonages in England half so
good. It may admit of improvement, however. Far be it from me to say
otherwise; and anything in reason a bow thrown out, perhaps though,
between ourselves, if there is one thing more than another my aversion,
it is a patched-on bow.']
speaker: General Tilney

quoteText:
Oh! Why do not you fit up this room, Mr. Tilney? What a
pity not to have it fitted up! It is the prettiest room I ever saw; it
is the prettiest room in the world!
subQuotationList: ['Oh! Why do not you fit up this room, Mr. Tilney? What a\npity not to have it fitted up! It is the prettiest room I ever saw; it\nis the prettiest room in the world!']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
I trust, that it will
very speedily be furnished: it waits only for a lady s taste!
subQuotationList: ['I trust,', 'that it will\nvery speedily be furnished: it waits only for a lady s taste!']
speaker: General Tilney

quoteText:
Well, if it was my house, I should never sit anywhere else. Oh! What a
sweet little cottage there is among the trees apple trees, too! It is
the prettiest cottage!
subQuotationList: ['Well, if it was my house, I should never sit anywhere else. Oh! What a\nsweet little cottage there is among the trees apple trees, too! It is\nthe prettiest cottage!']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
You like it you approve it as an object it is enough. Henry, remember
that Robinson is spoken to about it. The cottage remains.
subQuotationList: ['You like it you approve it as an object it is enough. Henry, remember\nthat Robinson is spoken to about it. The cottage remains.']
speaker: General Tilney

quoteText:
So much for Isabella, and for all our intimacy! She must think me an idiot, or she
could not have written so; but perhaps this has served to make her
character better known to me than mine is to her. I see what she has
been about. She is a vain coquette, and her tricks have not answered. I
do not believe she had ever any regard either for James or for me, and
I wish I had never known her.
subQuotationList:
['So much for Isabella,', 'and for all our intimacy! She must think me an idiot, or she
could not have written so; but perhaps this has served to make her
character better known to me than mine is to her. I see what she has
been about. She is a vain coquette, and her tricks have not answered. I
do not believe she had ever any regard either for James or for me, and
I wish I had never known her.']
speaker: Catherine Morland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Isabella Thorpe']], [['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['James Morland'], ['Isabella Thorpe']]]

quoteText: It will soon be as if you never had,
subQuotationList: ['It will soon be as if you never had,']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText:
There is but one thing that I cannot understand. I see that she has
had designs on Captain Tilney, which have not succeeded; but I do not
understand what Captain Tilney has been about all this time. Why should
he pay her such attentions as to make her quarrel with my brother, and
then fly off himself?
subQuotationList:
['There is but one thing that I cannot understand. I see that she has
had designs on Captain Tilney, which have not succeeded; but I do not
understand what Captain Tilney has been about all this time. Why should
he pay her such attentions as to make her quarrel with my brother, and
then fly off himself?']
speaker: Catherine Morland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Frederick Tilney '], ['Frederick Tilney '], ['Frederick Tilney '], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['James Morland']]]

quoteText:
I have very little to say for Frederick s motives, such as I believe
them to have been. He has his vanities as well as Miss Thorpe, and the
chief difference is, that, having a stronger head, they have not yet
injured himself. If the _effect_ of his behaviour does not justify him
with you, we had better not seek after the cause.
subQuotationList:
['I have very little to say for Frederick s motives, such as I believe
them to have been. He has his vanities as well as Miss Thorpe, and the
chief difference is, that, having a stronger head, they have not yet
injured himself. If the _effect_ of his behaviour does not justify him
with you, we had better not seek after the cause.']
speaker: Henry Tilney
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Frederick Tilney '], ['Frederick Tilney '], ['Frederick Tilney '], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Frederick Tilney '], ['Frederick Tilney '], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Henry Tilney', 'Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText: Then you do not suppose he ever really cared about her?
subQuotationList: ['Then you do not suppose he ever really cared about her?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: I am persuaded that he never did.
subQuotationList: ['I am persuaded that he never did.']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText: And only made believe to do so for mischief s sake?
subQuotationList: ['And only made believe to do so for mischief s sake?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Well, then, I must say that I do not like him at all. Though it has
turned out so well for us, I do not like him at all. As it happens,
there is no great harm done, because I do not think Isabella has any
heart to lose. But, suppose he had made her very much in love with
him?
subQuotationList:
['Well, then, I must say that I do not like him at all. Though it has
turned out so well for us, I do not like him at all. As it happens,
there is no great harm done, because I do not think Isabella has any
heart to lose. But, suppose he had made her very much in love with
him?']
speaker: Catherine Morland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Frederick Tilney '], ['Henry Tilney', 'Catherine Morland'], ['Frederick Tilney '], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Frederick Tilney '], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['Frederick Tilney ']]]

quoteText:
But we must first suppose Isabella to have had a heart to
lose consequently to have been a very different creature; and, in that
case, she would have met with very different treatment.
subQuotationList: ['But we must first suppose Isabella to have had a heart to\nlose consequently to have been a very different creature; and, in that\ncase, she would have met with very different treatment.']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText: It is very right that you should stand by your brother.
subQuotationList: ['It is very right that you should stand by your brother.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
And if you would stand by _yours_, you would not be much distressed by
the disappointment of Miss Thorpe. But your mind is warped by an innate
principle of general integrity, and therefore not accessible to the
cool reasonings of family partiality, or a desire of revenge.
subQuotationList:
['And if you would stand by _yours_, you would not be much distressed by
the disappointment of Miss Thorpe. But your mind is warped by an innate
principle of general integrity, and therefore not accessible to the
cool reasonings of family partiality, or a desire of revenge.']
speaker: Henry Tilney

quoteText:
Nay, if you can use such a word, I can urge you no farther. If you
think it long
subQuotationList: ['Nay, if you can use such a word, I can urge you no farther. If you\nthink it long']
speaker: Eleanor Tilney

quoteText:
Oh! No, I do not indeed. For my own pleasure, I could stay with you as
long again.
subQuotationList: ['Oh! No, I do not indeed. For my own pleasure, I could stay with you as\nlong again.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Good heaven! What can be the
matter?
subQuotationList: ['Good heaven! What can be the\nmatter?']
speaker: Eleanor Tilney
referringExpression: the first perturbation of surprise had passed away

quoteText:
My dear Catherine, you must not you
must not indeed I am quite
well. This kindness distracts me I cannot bear it I come to you on such
an errand!
subQuotationList:
['My dear Catherine, you must not you
must not indeed', 'I am quite
well. This kindness distracts me I cannot bear it I come to you on such
an errand!']
speaker: Eleanor Tilney
referringExpression: were Eleanor s first connected words

quoteText: Errand! To me!
subQuotationList: ['Errand! To me!']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: How shall I tell you! Oh! How shall I tell you!
subQuotationList: ['How shall I tell you! Oh! How shall I tell you!']
speaker: Eleanor Tilney

quoteText: Tis a messenger from Woodston!
subQuotationList: ['Tis a messenger from Woodston!']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText: You are mistaken, indeed, it is no one from Woodston. It is my father himself.
subQuotationList: ['You are mistaken, indeed,', 'it is no one from Woodston. It is my father himself.']
speaker: Eleanor Tilney

quoteText:
You are too good, I am sure, to think
the worse of me for the part I am obliged to perform. I am indeed a
most unwilling messenger. After what has so lately passed, so lately
been settled between us how joyfully, how thankfully on my side! as to
your continuing here as I hoped for many, many weeks longer, how can I
tell you that your kindness is not to be accepted and that the
happiness your company has hitherto given us is to be repaid by But I
must not trust myself with words. My dear Catherine, we are to part. My
father has recollected an engagement that takes our whole family away
on Monday. We are going to Lord Longtown s, near Hereford, for a
fortnight. Explanation and apology are equally impossible. I cannot
attempt either.
subQuotationList:
['You are too good, I am sure, to think
the worse of me for the part I am obliged to perform. I am indeed a
most unwilling messenger. After what has so lately passed, so lately
been settled between us how joyfully, how thankfully on my side! as to
your continuing here as I hoped for many, many weeks longer, how can I
tell you that your kindness is not to be accepted and that the
happiness your company has hitherto given us is to be repaid by But I
must not trust myself with words. My dear Catherine, we are to part. My
father has recollected an engagement that takes our whole family away
on Monday. We are going to Lord Longtown s, near Hereford, for a
fortnight. Explanation and apology are equally impossible. I cannot
attempt either.']
speaker: Eleanor Tilney
referringExpression: Eleanor endeavouring to collect herself and speak with firmness but with eyes still cast down soon went on
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Catherine Morland'], ['Eleanor Tilney', 'Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Henry Tilney', 'Eleanor Tilney', 'General Tilney'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Eleanor Tilney', 'Catherine Morland'], ['General Tilney'], ['Eleanor Tilney', 'Henry Tilney', 'General Tilney', 'Captain Tilney'], ['Henry Tilney', 'Eleanor Tilney', 'Frederick Tilney ', 'General Tilney']]]

quoteText:
My dear Eleanor, do not be so distressed. A second engagement must give way
to a first. I am very, very sorry we are to part so soon, and so
suddenly too; but I am not offended, indeed I am not. I can finish my
visit here, you know, at any time; or I hope you will come to me. Can
you, when you return from this lord s, come to Fullerton?
subQuotationList:
['My dear Eleanor,', 'do not be so distressed. A second engagement must give way
to a first. I am very, very sorry we are to part so soon, and so
suddenly too; but I am not offended, indeed I am not. I can finish my
visit here, you know, at any time; or I hope you will come to me. Can
you, when you return from this lord s, come to Fullerton?']
speaker: Catherine Morland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Eleanor Tilney']], [['Eleanor Tilney', 'Catherine Morland'], ['Eleanor Tilney'], ['Eleanor Tilney'], ['Eleanor Tilney']]]

quoteText: It will not be in my power, Catherine.
subQuotationList: ['It will not be in my power, Catherine.']
speaker: Eleanor Tilney

quoteText: Come when you can, then.
subQuotationList: ['Come when you can, then.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Monday so soon
as Monday; and you _all_ go. Well, I am certain of I shall be able to
take leave, however. I need not go till just before you do, you know.
Do not be distressed, Eleanor, I can go on Monday very well. My father
and mother s having no notice of it is of very little consequence. The
general will send a servant with me, I dare say, half the way and then
I shall soon be at Salisbury, and then I am only nine miles from home.
subQuotationList:
['Monday so soon
as Monday; and you _all_ go. Well, I am certain of I shall be able to
take leave, however. I need not go till just before you do, you know.
Do not be distressed, Eleanor, I can go on Monday very well. My father
and mother s having no notice of it is of very little consequence. The
general will send a servant with me, I dare say, half the way and then
I shall soon be at Salisbury, and then I am only nine miles from home.']
speaker: Catherine Morland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Eleanor Tilney'], ['Eleanor Tilney'], ['Eleanor Tilney'], ['Eleanor Tilney'], ['Mrs. Morland', 'Mr. Morland'], ['General Tilney']]]

quoteText:
Ah, Catherine! Were it settled so, it would be somewhat less
intolerable, though in such common attentions you would have received
but half what you ought. But how can I tell you? tomorrow morning is
fixed for your leaving us, and not even the hour is left to your
choice; the very carriage is ordered, and will be here at seven
o clock, and no servant will be offered you.
subQuotationList:
['Ah, Catherine! Were it settled so, it would be somewhat less
intolerable, though in such common attentions you would have received
but half what you ought. But how can I tell you? tomorrow morning is
fixed for your leaving us, and not even the hour is left to your
choice; the very carriage is ordered, and will be here at seven
o clock, and no servant will be offered you.']
speaker: Eleanor Tilney
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Henry Tilney', 'Eleanor Tilney', 'General Tilney'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText:
I could hardly believe
my senses, when I heard it; and no displeasure, no resentment that you
can feel at this moment, however justly great, can be more than I
myself but I must not talk of what I felt. Oh! That I could suggest
anything in extenuation! Good God! What will your father and mother
say! After courting you from the protection of real friends to
this almost double distance from your home, to have you driven out of
the house, without the considerations even of decent civility! Dear,
dear Catherine, in being the bearer of such a message, I seem guilty
myself of all its insult; yet, I trust you will acquit me, for you must
have been long enough in this house to see that I am but a nominal
mistress of it, that my real power is nothing.
subQuotationList:
['I could hardly believe
my senses, when I heard it; and no displeasure, no resentment that you
can feel at this moment, however justly great, can be more than I
myself but I must not talk of what I felt. Oh! That I could suggest
anything in extenuation! Good God! What will your father and mother
say! After courting you from the protection of real friends to
this almost double distance from your home, to have you driven out of
the house, without the considerations even of decent civility! Dear,

myself of all its insult; yet, I trust you will acquit me, for you must
have been long enough in this house to see that I am but a nominal
mistress of it, that my real power is nothing.']
speaker: Eleanor Tilney
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Catherine Morland'], ['Mrs. Morland', 'Mr. Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText: Have I offended the general?
subQuotationList: ['Have I offended the general?']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Alas! For my feelings as a daughter, all that I know, all that I
answer for, is that you can have given him no just cause of offence. He
certainly is greatly, very greatly discomposed; I have seldom seen him
more so. His temper is not happy, and something has now occurred to
ruffle it in an uncommon degree; some disappointment, some vexation,
which just at this moment seems important, but which I can hardly
suppose you to have any concern in, for how is it possible?
subQuotationList:
['Alas! For my feelings as a daughter, all that I know, all that I
answer for, is that you can have given him no just cause of offence. He
certainly is greatly, very greatly discomposed; I have seldom seen him
more so. His temper is not happy, and something has now occurred to
ruffle it in an uncommon degree; some disappointment, some vexation,
which just at this moment seems important, but which I can hardly
suppose you to have any concern in, for how is it possible?']
speaker: Eleanor Tilney
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Catherine Morland'], ['General Tilney'], ['General Tilney'], ['General Tilney'], ['General Tilney'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText:
I am sure, I am very
sorry if I have offended him. It was the last thing I would willingly
have done. But do not be unhappy, Eleanor. An engagement, you know,
must be kept. I am only sorry it was not recollected sooner, that I
might have written home. But it is of very little consequence.
subQuotationList:
['I am sure,', 'I am very
sorry if I have offended him. It was the last thing I would willingly
have done. But do not be unhappy, Eleanor. An engagement, you know,
must be kept. I am only sorry it was not recollected sooner, that I
might have written home. But it is of very little consequence.']
speaker: Catherine Morland
Eleanor Tilney
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText:
Oh, the journey is nothing. Do not think about that. And if we are to
part, a few hours sooner or later, you know, makes no difference. I can
be ready by seven. Let me be called in time.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, the journey is nothing. Do not think about that. And if we are to\npart, a few hours sooner or later, you know, makes no difference. I can\nbe ready by seven. Let me be called in time.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
I shall see you in
the morning.
subQuotationList: ['I shall see you in\nthe morning.']
speaker: Eleanor Tilney
referringExpression: Eleanor saw that she wished to be alone and believing it better for each that they should avoid any further conversation now left her with

quoteText:
You _must_ write to me, Catherine, you _must_ let me hear
from you as soon as possible. Till I know you to be safe at home, I
shall not have an hour s comfort. For _one_ letter, at all risks, all
hazards, I must entreat. Let me have the satisfaction of knowing that
you are safe at Fullerton, and have found your family well, and then,
till I can ask for your correspondence as I ought to do, I will not
expect more. Direct to me at Lord Longtown s, and, I must ask it, under
cover to Alice.
subQuotationList:
['You _must_ write to me, Catherine,', 'you _must_ let me hear
from you as soon as possible. Till I know you to be safe at home, I
shall not have an hour s comfort. For _one_ letter, at all risks, all
hazards, I must entreat. Let me have the satisfaction of knowing that
you are safe at Fullerton, and have found your family well, and then,
till I can ask for your correspondence as I ought to do, I will not
expect more. Direct to me at Lord Longtown s, and, I must ask it, under
cover to Alice.']
speaker: Eleanor Tilney
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland']], [['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['James Morland', 'Mr. Morland', 'Mrs. Morland'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText:
No, Eleanor, if you are not allowed to receive a letter from me, I am
sure I had better not write. There can be no doubt of my getting home
safe.
subQuotationList: ['No, Eleanor, if you are not allowed to receive a letter from me, I am\nsure I had better not write. There can be no doubt of my getting home\nsafe.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
I cannot wonder at your feelings. I will not
importune you. I will trust to your own kindness of heart when I am at
a distance from you.
subQuotationList: ['I cannot wonder at your feelings. I will not\nimportune you. I will trust to your own kindness of heart when I am at\na distance from you.']
speaker: Eleanor Tilney

quoteText: Oh, Eleanor, I _will_ write to you indeed.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, Eleanor, I _will_ write to you indeed.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
My dear, you give yourself a great deal of needless
trouble, depend upon it, it is something not
at all worth understanding.
subQuotationList: ['My dear, you give yourself a great deal of needless\ntrouble,', 'depend upon it, it is something not\nat all worth understanding.']
speaker: Mrs. Morland

quoteText:
I can allow for his wishing Catherine away, when he recollected this
engagement, but why not do it civilly?
subQuotationList: ['I can allow for his wishing Catherine away, when he recollected this\nengagement,', 'but why not do it civilly?']
speaker: Sarah

quoteText:
I am sorry for the young people, they must
have a sad time of it; but as for anything else, it is no matter now;
Catherine is safe at home, and our comfort does not depend upon General
Tilney.
subQuotationList:
['I am sorry for the young people,', 'they must
have a sad time of it; but as for anything else, it is no matter now;
Catherine is safe at home, and our comfort does not depend upon General
Tilney.']
speaker: Mrs. Morland

quoteText:
Well, I
am glad I did not know of your journey at the time; but now it is all
over, perhaps there is no great harm done. It is always good for young
people to be put upon exerting themselves; and you know, my dear
Catherine, you always were a sad little scatter-brained creature; but
now you must have been forced to have your wits about you, with so much
changing of chaises and so forth; and I hope it will appear that you
have not left anything behind you in any of the pockets.
subQuotationList:
['Well,', 'I
am glad I did not know of your journey at the time; but now it is all
over, perhaps there is no great harm done. It is always good for young
people to be put upon exerting themselves; and you know, my dear
Catherine, you always were a sad little scatter-brained creature; but
now you must have been forced to have your wits about you, with so much
changing of chaises and so forth; and I hope it will appear that you
have not left anything behind you in any of the pockets.']
speaker: Mrs. Morland
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText:
This has been a strange acquaintance, soon made and soon ended. I am sorry it happens
so, for Mrs. Allen thought them very pretty kind of young people; and
you were sadly out of luck too in your Isabella. Ah! Poor James! Well,
we must live and learn; and the next new friends you make I hope will
be better worth keeping.
subQuotationList:
['This has been a strange acquaintance,', 'soon made and soon ended. I am sorry it happens
so, for Mrs. Allen thought them very pretty kind of young people; and
you were sadly out of luck too in your Isabella. Ah! Poor James! Well,
we must live and learn; and the next new friends you make I hope will
be better worth keeping.']
speaker: Mrs. Morland
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mrs. Allen'], ['Henry Tilney', 'Eleanor Tilney'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['James Morland'], ['Catherine Morland', 'Mrs. Morland', 'James Morland'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText:
No friend can be better
worth keeping than Eleanor.
subQuotationList: ['No friend can be better\nworth keeping than Eleanor.']
speaker: Catherine Morland
referringExpression: Catherine coloured as she warmly answered

quoteText:
If so, my dear, I dare say you will meet again some time or other; do
not be uneasy. It is ten to one but you are thrown together again in
the course of a few years; and then what a pleasure it will be!
subQuotationList: ['If so, my dear, I dare say you will meet again some time or other; do\nnot be uneasy. It is ten to one but you are thrown together again in\nthe course of a few years; and then what a pleasure it will be!']
speaker: Mrs. Morland

quoteText:
We are sorry for him, but
otherwise there is no harm done in the match going off; for it could
not be a desirable thing to have him engaged to a girl whom we had not
the smallest acquaintance with, and who was so entirely without
fortune; and now, after such behaviour, we cannot think at all well of
her. Just at present it comes hard to poor James; but that will not
last forever; and I dare say he will be a discreeter man all his life,
for the foolishness of his first choice.
subQuotationList:
['We are sorry for him,', 'but
otherwise there is no harm done in the match going off; for it could
not be a desirable thing to have him engaged to a girl whom we had not
the smallest acquaintance with, and who was so entirely without

her. Just at present it comes hard to poor James; but that will not
last forever; and I dare say he will be a discreeter man all his life,
for the foolishness of his first choice.']
speaker: Mrs. Morland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Morland'], ['James Morland']], [['James Morland'], ['Mrs. Morland', 'Mr. Morland'], ['Mrs. Morland', 'Mr. Morland'], ['Isabella Thorpe'], ['James Morland'], ['James Morland'], ['James Morland'], ['James Morland']]]

quoteText:
Catherine took us quite by surprise yesterday evening, She
travelled all the way post by herself, and knew nothing of coming till
Saturday night; for General Tilney, from some odd fancy or other, all
of a sudden grew tired of having her there, and almost turned her out
of the house. Very unfriendly, certainly; and he must be a very odd
man; but we are so glad to have her amongst us again! And it is a great
comfort to find that she is not a poor helpless creature, but can shift
very well for herself.
subQuotationList:
['Catherine took us quite by surprise yesterday evening,', 'She
travelled all the way post by herself, and knew nothing of coming till
Saturday night; for General Tilney, from some odd fancy or other, all

comfort to find that she is not a poor helpless creature, but can shift
very well for herself.']
speaker: Mrs. Morland

quoteText:
I really have not
patience with the general
subQuotationList: ['I really have not\npatience with the general']
speaker: Mrs. Allen
referringExpression: hers with the addition of this single remark

quoteText:
I
really have not patience with the general,
subQuotationList: ['I\nreally have not patience with the general,']
speaker: Mrs. Allen

quoteText:
Only think, my dear, of my having got that frightful great rent
in my best Mechlin so charmingly mended, before I left Bath, that one
can hardly see where it was. I must show it you some day or other. Bath
is a nice place, Catherine, after all. I assure you I did not above
half like coming away. Mrs. Thorpe s being there was such a comfort to
us, was not it? You know, you and I were quite forlorn at first.
subQuotationList:
['Only think, my dear, of my having got that frightful great rent
in my best Mechlin so charmingly mended, before I left Bath, that one
can hardly see where it was. I must show it you some day or other. Bath
is a nice place, Catherine, after all. I assure you I did not above
half like coming away. Mrs. Thorpe s being there was such a comfort to
us, was not it? You know, you and I were quite forlorn at first.']
speaker: Mrs. Allen
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Mrs. Thorpe'], ['Mrs. Allen', 'Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText: Yes, but _that_ did not last long,
subQuotationList: ['Yes, but _that_ did not last long,']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
Very true: we soon met with Mrs. Thorpe, and then we wanted for
nothing. My dear, do not you think these silk gloves wear very well? I
put them on new the first time of our going to the Lower Rooms, you
know, and I have worn them a great deal since. Do you remember that
evening?
subQuotationList:
['Very true: we soon met with Mrs. Thorpe, and then we wanted for
nothing. My dear, do not you think these silk gloves wear very well? I
put them on new the first time of our going to the Lower Rooms, you
know, and I have worn them a great deal since. Do you remember that
evening?']
speaker: Mrs. Allen
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Allen', 'Catherine Morland'], ['Mrs. Thorpe'], ['Mrs. Allen', 'Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText: Do I! Oh! Perfectly.
subQuotationList: ['Do I! Oh! Perfectly.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
It was very agreeable, was not it? Mr. Tilney drank tea with us, and I
always thought him a great addition, he is so very agreeable. I have a
notion you danced with him, but am not quite sure. I remember I had my
favourite gown on.
subQuotationList:
['It was very agreeable, was not it? Mr. Tilney drank tea with us, and I
always thought him a great addition, he is so very agreeable. I have a
notion you danced with him, but am not quite sure. I remember I had my
favourite gown on.']
speaker: Mrs. Allen
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Henry Tilney'], ['Mrs. Allen', 'Catherine Morland'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Henry Tilney'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Henry Tilney']]]

quoteText:
I really have not patience with the
general! Such an agreeable, worthy man as he seemed to be! I do not
suppose, Mrs. Morland, you ever saw a better-bred man in your life. His
lodgings were taken the very day after he left them, Catherine. But no
wonder; Milsom Street, you know.
subQuotationList:
['I really have not patience with the
general! Such an agreeable, worthy man as he seemed to be! I do not
suppose, Mrs. Morland, you ever saw a better-bred man in your life. His
lodgings were taken the very day after he left them, Catherine. But no
wonder; Milsom Street, you know.']
speaker: Mrs. Allen

quoteText:
My dear Catherine, I am afraid you are growing quite a fine lady. I do
not know when poor Richard s cravats would be done, if he had no friend
but you. Your head runs too much upon Bath; but there is a time for
everything a time for balls and plays, and a time for work. You have
had a long run of amusement, and now you must try to be useful.
subQuotationList:
['My dear Catherine, I am afraid you are growing quite a fine lady. I do
not know when poor Richard s cravats would be done, if he had no friend
but you. Your head runs too much upon Bath; but there is a time for
everything a time for balls and plays, and a time for work. You have
had a long run of amusement, and now you must try to be useful.']
speaker: Mrs. Morland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText: her head did not run upon Bath much.
subQuotationList: ['her head did not run upon Bath much.']
speaker: Catherine Morland
referringExpression: Catherine took up her work directly saying

quoteText:
Then you are fretting about General Tilney, and that is very simple of
you; for ten to one whether you ever see him again. You should never
fret about trifles.
subQuotationList: ['Then you are fretting about General Tilney, and that is very simple of\nyou; for ten to one whether you ever see him again. You should never\nfret about trifles.']
speaker: Mrs. Morland
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Catherine Morland'], ['General Tilney'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['Catherine Morland'], ['General Tilney'], ['Catherine Morland']]]

quoteText:
I hope, my Catherine, you
are not getting out of humour with home because it is not so grand as
Northanger. That would be turning your visit into an evil indeed.
Wherever you are you should always be contented, but especially at
home, because there you must spend the most of your time. I did not
quite like, at breakfast, to hear you talk so much about the French
bread at Northanger.
subQuotationList:
['I hope, my Catherine, you

quoteText:
I am sure I do not care about the bread. It is all the same to me what
I eat.
subQuotationList: ['I am sure I do not care about the bread. It is all the same to me what\nI eat.']
speaker: Catherine Morland

quoteText:
There is a very clever essay in one of the books upstairs upon much
such a subject, about young girls that have been spoilt for home by
great acquaintance The Mirror, I think. I will look it out for you some
day or other, because I am sure it will do you good.
subQuotationList:
['There is a very clever essay in one of the books upstairs upon much
such a subject, about young girls that have been spoilt for home by
great acquaintance The Mirror, I think. I will look it out for you some
day or other, because I am sure it will do you good.']
speaker: Mrs. Morland

quoteText:
You may see the house from this
window, sir,
subQuotationList: ['You may see the house from this\nwindow, sir,']
speaker: Sarah
referringExpression: was information on Sarah s side

quoteText:
Catherine would make a sad, heedless young
housekeeper to be sure,
subQuotationList: ['Catherine would make a sad, heedless young\nhousekeeper to be sure,']
speaker: Mrs. Morland
referringExpression: was her mother s foreboding remark

quoteText: Your Ladyship!
subQuotationList: ['Your Ladyship!']
